content:
Posted: January 11
												I have to be completely honest with you: I didn't like Cave story when I first saw it. “Meh, some pixel platformer with a pistol… what's with all the hype? Boring!”Out of sheer curiosity, I had to give it another try and a little more time. And then it grew on me. It fascinated me. I couldn't stop. Suddenly I was totally in love with this game.What's its secret? Nice visuals and music, adorable characters, an interesting story, well-balanced gameplay (with some really challenging options for the fans), secrets and cool achievements… I guess none of these ingredients is 100% exceptionally one-of-a-kind original, but somehow together they mix into an almost perfect chef d'œuvre.


Why yes I do! 
A Screenshot of Cave Story+
By: facedancer




Play this game. Replay it on Halloween. Replay it on Christmas. It's a real pleasure.Then download the Cave story remix project[kwixmusic.com] and listen to it at home and at work. And replay again.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												Cave Story was (not technically, but in a way and with a story) my first PC game. I remember being on a budget and my consoles packed up 3,000 miles away. I remember hearing about this game, finding it with the aid of Google Translate and nabbing the excellent fan translation. And then I experienced the first game that made me think "this is a console quality experience." It was highly polished and didn't require any fiddling to make work. It had gorgeous pixel art graphics and fantastic chip tune music. The story was a tad hard to follow but very interesting and engaging. The game dripped with atmosphere. And ... it was all dreamed up and created by one man!Flash forward. In the meantime I beat this game on PC, I picked up the remake with optional slightly enhanced artwork and sound and beat it on Wii. And now I pick up that same game on Steam and start playing through it once again.And you know what? I plan on getting the 3D remake on 3DS next! There aren't many games I don't hesitate to play through again and again and even fewer I purchase again and again. Cave Story is up there in that elite list of mine. It is surely worthy of being called a classic and it is a game every gamer who grew up in the 8 and 16 bit eras will enjoy with an odd sense of nostalgia. Those growing up with gaming right now ought to take a chance and play through Cave Story.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Of course the game is amazing and deserves a purchase. However, Cave Story has a huge glaring issue that you need to be warned about if you've never played. The game is cryptic as all hell. If you do not follow an extremely specific list of minute tasks (don't talk to this person, talk to this person a second time, examine an object that doesn't appear to be examinable, make this really long jump without falling, don't follow this person until you get this item, etc) then you cannot get the best ending. I am understandably upset, because even when using a guide, I missed one tiny little step (didn't talk to a person twice) and now the best ending is off limits on my current playthrough. I now have to start all over just because I missed one small step. This cryptic method of game development irritates me to no end and should be left as a relic of the NES era. Putting all that aside, Cave Story is still one of the best games on Steam and you should buy it rapidly. I just wanted to prepare you for one of the big problems of the game.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												I thought I had already recommended this one... guess not. Anyways, I already played this game a few years ago, but bought it again on Steam when it came out because, well, it's just that good. For fans of old-school 2D action-platformers, this game is for you. It has frantic shooting elements similar to action games like Contra and Gunstar Heroes, but it's done in the exploratory 'Metroidvania' style. The gameplay is spot-on fantastic, and it's full of cool characters, maps, puzzles and secrets. It's also a tough challenge, especially if you want to go for the secret "true" ending. For fans of the genre, this game is a must-have. Pick it up, especially on sale. Note: I highly recommend using a gamepad. Think twice if you don't have one.

												I strongly dislike platformers as a genre, and I think that's mostly because I'm terrible at them and get easily infuriated with tricky jumps and wonkey control precision. Because of this, I would typically condemn this game right off the bat for being just another platformer to pass on..However, Cave Story has a very unique charm to it; no, I didn't play much through it, I was terrible and got frustrated. I think this would be a fantastic game for fans of the genre and the gameplay style and though it's not for me, I think Cave Story would be great for others. Definitely recommend.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												Cave Story is a fantastic game and Cave Story+ just builds onto what was already great about it.If you haven't tried the original just go to http://cavestory.org/ and get it already!For an list of differences between Cave Story (Original freeware version; 2004), Cave Story+ (Steam port; 2011), and other Cave Story versions check out http://cavestory.wikia.com/wiki/Version_differencesAlthough the steam version includes a fair bit of bells and whistles (like running at 60FPS instead of 50FPS), the drawbacks I see with it are:• No proper widescreen/16:9 support.• Curse Broken achievement has been bugged since release so good luck getting only 99% completion• Anytime you complete a challenge mode it crashes the game (it still saves your replay & time but it's annoying.)• "View Rankings" button they included in the challenges modes doesn't work/crashes the game, presumably there was going to be steam leaderboards that were never implemented.It's pretty much nit picking and they could possibly fix the issues with it but it's almost 5 years since it released on steam and nothing has changed.I'd still consider Cave Story+ an upgrade and worth it if you enjoyed the original.I got this during a sale a while back for $2.49 so it depends if you're willing to pay full price or not.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												If I had to find a flaw in this game, the only thing I could point out is the location of some save points. Because it's just annoying to have to retrace your steps for a big chunk of road and watch the same cutscene over and over when you're trying to beat a boss, especially if you're trying to complete Hard Mode or to unlock the "Untouchable" and "Unstoppable" achievements. Everything else is just remarkable. It's the definition of Classic: a perfect Metroidvania platformer with great story and lots of secrets to be found. It's not a coincidence that Cave Story is considered by many the best indie game ever made. At least in its genre, it surely is.EDIT: I kinda hate Nicalis for introducing in the game achievements that are practically impossible to obtain. I mean, completing Blood Stained Sanctuary without ANY health upgrade, are they even serious? Have they at least TESTED if this thing was feasible AT ALL? I couldn't literally find ANYONE on the web that managed to do that. The very few people that unlocked the corrisponding achievement on their profile probably used cheats. This is no good. In the original version of the game there's no mention of such a challenge, for a reason.Oh, and the "Curse Broken" ach is -oh the irony - broken. And nobody will ever fix it. Great job guys. Really.

content:
Posted: March 27
												If you like a metroidvania platformer with a great soundtrack, then this is a game for you. It's a decently long game, 10 hours or more, maybe? But that's only the main game, there are so many other things that you can do in the game the will change the ending of Cave Story+. There are three ends, Bad, Neutral, and Best. Getting the Best ending will take you a very long time, it took me 28 hours to do, but it was very satisfying. Also, the story is deep and you can get attached to the characters *cough* *Curly Brace* *cough*. There are also some hard to find secrets hidden is some areas. Like Curly Brace's panties, and by getting them you unlock another game mode called Curly Story. Anyway, I recommend this game, it's one of my childhood favorites for sure.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Cave Story offers a Metroidvania gameplay, and it does it very well. This game was made by 1 person, everything. The music, art, and programming was just one dude. The art style is okay in "HD" mode, but consider playing through the game with original music and non-HD first, I feel that it is more charming at it's original state. Basically, you're a guy who, you guessed it, fights his way through multiple caves (and other places too), and this dude also has to deal with a bunny rabbit soap opera. The story is goofy, but very compelling. The script is awesome, melding happy, sad, and funny all togther. You'll have many fun weapons to use through out the game, and they all can be leveled up by collecting fallen Doritos which are relinquished from enemies when you kill em. But the weapons can de-level if you get hit too many times, making a unique challenge factor. This Steam version offers a new hard mode if you are a masochist, since the original difficulty is nothing to scoff at. The music is very memorable, and so well done too, setting the appropriate tone for each "cave". There are multiple endings, easter eggs galore, and a hidden final area/boss, which is a blast to speed run though once you unlock it.Do yourself a favor, buy and complete this game.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												A beautiful remake of a fun and challenging game. If you aren't looking to spend the money, you can still find the original as freeware online. Pixel did such an amazing job with this game that I was happy to see it get a remake (though I would suggest waiting until you see it on sale either through Humble Bundle or Steam Sale.. the price tag is rather high for the length of the game).It's got tight side-scrolling action, wonderful pixel art and soundtrack (particularly the remake), challenging obstacles, multiple endings and unlocks, and a surprising amount of replayability.It's impressive to think that the original is a decade old and was developed by one man in his free time as freeware.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This is arguably the best game I've ever played. Just the feel of it ever since I first played it was just too much fun! I've played it through on PC, 3DS, Wii and bought it again on the Nintendo Shop on my 3DS(Classic) and did a hard mode run with the Machine Gun and Bubbline(Pains me to not use king's blade). So I decided, why not buy CS+ as well since it was on sale?! And even though it's like my 3rd time buying it again, I don't think I will ever regret the purchase! Just the diversity and the play style which causes for a tad bit grinding and the punishment system of trying to teach you to not get hit and be tactical. It also has a kind of feel like the game itself is telling you to not give up and be a hero! I mean that is something you almost never see in video games these days.It also has these really nice transitions of bringing you from upbeat to depressing and it really just shows how a real villian is supposed to act instead of just a clash of ideals and opinions with the whole thing between Misery(Absoloutley <3 Misery she's so casual) and The Doctor(Just a downright jerk) going against Quote and Curly Brace. It just let you feel you were on a real cause instead of it just being a snuff game where the main character was mad the antagonist♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥in his corn flakes. It even shows little things where the Villians start to step their game up and try harder instead of just refurbishing their same plan or just sitting back and watching you become OP. Made you feel like: "Hey, I'm getting stronger, faster and much more cool! I can really do this! Just look at me from start to finish! I started with a dinky pistol, now I'm shooting laser beams while I have stars following me!

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												A beautiful remake of a fun and challenging game. If you aren't looking to spend the money, you can still find the original as freeware online. Pixel did such an amazing job with this game that I was happy to see it get a remake (though I would suggest waiting until you see it on sale either through Humble Bundle or Steam Sale.. the price tag is rather high for the length of the game).It's got tight side-scrolling action, wonderful pixel art and soundtrack (particularly the remake), challenging obstacles, multiple endings and unlocks, and a surprising amount of replayability.It's impressive to think that the original is a decade old and was developed by one man in his free time as freeware.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												This is one of the best games I have ever played. It gives less than subtle nods to like platformers such as Megaman and Metroid, but has a very deep story. Characters do die and many of their fates rest on you and your decisions. While this game has a cute art style and happy music, it can be a very dark game when a favorite character(s) die because of something you didn't do. This game has multiple endings that feel incredibly different ie. not Mass Effect 3. This game is a blast, but is somewhat difficult to get the best ending. If you aren't completely sold I reccomend playing a bit of the original version for free  at www.cavestory.org so you know that you will enjoy it. One of my top 10 favorite games for sure, quite possibly top 5. All in all give this game a try if you want your mind blown. Fans of old school and new school games can easily enjoy this game if they are decent at platformers. If not there is an easy mode exclusive to cave story+ which does prevent you from getting the best ending. Also, I reccomend a controller. Did I mention that this game was completed totally by one guy?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												7.5/10Cave Story will move you. The story is beautifully ominous and rich with immersion. It is a game that can be picked up time after time and still maintain it's replayability and fun. As someone who never played the original Cave Story, this game came as a great shock to me. It reminded me of oldschool platformer games like Metroid, where you could explore, find new items, get upgrades, discover secrets, whatever you so desired. A huge amount of games that try to do that can't pull it off. They do exactly the opposite of what Cave Story does. Cave Story gives the player a sense of exploration; something that can't be crafted in many games. The player IS the main character, and everything that happens will affect the player as it did the character. What detracts from this game is the same thing that detracts from every game of this genre; things like getting stuck on the same level over and over, getting stuck, and other things of the sort. I'm not going to lower this games rating because of that drastically, purely because that is sometimes what makes the game the game that it is. Example being in Zelda; you will remember the water temple more because it was a pain in the butt to beat. Things that like make Cave Story all the more memorable, and making it a game I will think about time and time again. Great indie game that everyone should play.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2012
												Cave Story is a retro metroidvania: a retroidvania, if you will.  The game is played with simple moving, jumping, and shooting mechanics with an emphasis on fighting but the game also requires a fair bit of platforming.  The weapons all function very differently.  They are suited for different situations and really mix up the gameplay as do the area-specific enemies.  The boss fights in particular will always force you to deal with something new and they are great fun.The characters are suprisingly deep and they are what really made the game memorable for me.  Their personalities are communicated very well and it's easy to become attached to many of them.  The plot setup is fairly cliché but the characters and encounters keep it engaging and the story progresses at a very good pace.The game seems to have a pretty linear progression at first, but there are secrets to be found, several sidequests, optional weapons, and multiple endings which all make the game that much richer.Cave Story has great gameplay, a good story, memorable characters, and to top it off, an exceptional soundtrack.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												1st lets establish what this game is 


YouTube™ Video: Cave Story WITH LYRICS - brentalfloss 

			Views: 2,144,261		

			Get the mp3 on iTunes! http://itunes.com/brentalfloss You can also get it at Bandcamp: http://bit.ly/13tRwEV It's also available on Google Play (formerly "Android Store"): http://goo.gl/muFLk And...		

 (Warning Minor spoilers)So now we have an understanding what this game is about let’s move to the next subjectAlso if you want my opinions on the story, it’s probably one of the best video game tales ever toldGameplay: -The only game I have ever play that has a similar control scheme to this game is Awesomenauts and even that it’s a bit farfetched.-Unlike in Awesomnauts (where you aim with your mouse) you control your directions via arrows keys with no diangular directionsWeapons:    -You have 6 weapons on yourself late game with 4 you can upgrade/ trade off if you want to on your journey.-Each weapon is extremely fun and unique with some being more than others but all weapons have their place in the world where it would be the most efficient   -Each weapon can be level up to 3 times by collecting triangle bits that fall out of each enemy (XP) In most cases higher levels mean more damage and more ability power for the weapon (I won't spoil the effects for you)-Some weapons level in different ways (mostly late game)    -When you get hit by the enemy your XP on your weapon goes down by a certain amount, different weapons level faster and different weapons lose more when you get hit (kinda like armor effect)Other:-The games life system is based on health and invincibility frames after getting hit, health is restored usually on enemy drops or in map pickups.  -Mid game the difficulty curve shoots up like a ♥♥♥♥ing rocket ship, it mellows out after that part but the very last level (The secret ending) is near impossible to do without hours-days of practice and knowledge. I would highly recommended to look up a speedrun and/or walkthrough of that part if you’re getting stuck on a certain section of it (especially with the very last 2 parts because you have 10 seconds to figure it out and to many ways to mess up). The 1st 3 parts of it is UNfairly challenging and can be learn given enough time.Soundtrack/OST: One of the best OSTs ever made IMO, be sure to have the game set to “Remaster”http://cavestory.wikia.com/wiki/Version_differences <-- If you want to know about the different versions of this game and their assets.Main Problem with the game:-The branching paths... The paths are few and far between but taking the wrong path will give you the lesser ending + weaker items (and nothing more)  -The paths are not obvious which mean you can end up making a mistake where you end up deeply regretting latter (which usually leads to messing with trainers to get back where you want to be)-So with this I have to regrettable say, it’s in your best interest to grab a guide that at least tells you about these branching paths and which ones to take.Conclusion: Overlooking the game problems, I think this is a game that EVERYONE should play/try.-IMO there’s something whimsical about this game that makes it special for me and also IMO it would be unfair to yourselves if you went on living without never touching this game.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												If you ask yourself, how many people did it take to make this awesome game, only 1 person made this game literally and its known as the best indie game as of now. Daisuke Amaya also known as Pixel made this game for 5 years during his free time which sounds great.You play the role of a unknown person who wakes up in the first cave, im not joking thats what the 1st level of the game is called. You lookaround the cave and 'steal' a gun from a guy who is sleeping. You soon find yourself in a village called Mimiga Village, a race of bunnies who are kidnapped from the doctor, not the one who helps you with your body i mean the one who kills you for no reason just to possess something.As you progress through the game you find a girl who was a human but got transformed into a mimiga ( dont worry only 2 people got turned like that, every mimiga is not a human) and asks your help to escape the island with her family. You realize you are on a giant island that was a piece of the surface (its not Earth). and that your a robot who was sent to the island to kill the mimiga but you got seperated from your partner and you forgot your name (its a stupid one but im not spoiling that much). Your job in the game is, find your partnet, save the mimiga, rescue the captured mimigas from the docter, kill the docters minions and himself and 1 more thing that affects the entire island.This game is actually harder than it looks as you find missle upgrades, health upgrades, new guns and most importantly, what you must and musnt do. There is 3 ending in the game, bad, ok and good ending. getting the good ending is hard as you must get certain items and not pick up items.I give this game 9 out of 10 because Daisuke Amaya really took his time to make an amazing game all by himself, the music,the gameplay and the graphics. The story gets more interesting as your progress through the game and the gameplay is equevalent to everyone well not the ending as it takes hardcore players to finish.I forgot to mention once you beat the game, you can play as your partner and everything is switch, now the partner is looking for you but its not worth sin e its the exact same thing but with diffrent dialologue.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												Great version of Cave Story. I'm not a big fan of the new graphics and soundtrack but luckily you can change them to the originals. There were a few localization changes from the freeware version like Grasstown being changed to Bushlands and Balrog's "Oh yeah!" instead of "Huzzah!" but these are extremely minor nitpicks. There are some really fun challenges added as well, and a few other extras here and there, like halloween and christmas reskins when you play on October 31st and December 25th.The game also has controller support that works well with fully rebindable controls.I'm glad one of my favorite games is on steam, I hope they add trading cards at some point, I'd love a Cave Story background.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												It's amazing what a single person can accomplish when they set their mind to a task, isn't it? Cave Story was made by one person, a Japanese developer with the handle "Pixel", and when it was originally released (for free) it set the indie gaming scene on fire. Not only did it look and sound wonderful, with a memorable soundtrack and gorgoues sprite artwork, but it was also huge, potentially taking upwards of 8 hours to finish. Heck, it even had a secret ending which sent determined players dodging and blasting their way through a ruin as it crumbled around you, to fight and defeat one last ultimate boss enemy. And one person was responsible for doing EVERYTHING.You play as a deceptively cute robot - who initially is not named - stranded on a vast and labyrinthine island suspended in the sky. As you explore, you meet the mimigas and learn of their plight: a crazed Doctor wishes to expose them to a certain flower, which causes the mimiga to fly into an uncontrollable rage and attack anything in sight. But to what end? To wage war on the planet below the island, and elevate him to the status of undisputed ruler. He's a villains villain, a real moustache-twirler, and to the credit of the game, both the baddies and the heroes in this game are really memorable. The story isn't so original, but the characterisation is really strong so you'll care, and want to help the mimiga, and want to learn about your own mysterious origins.Exploration is a big aspect of Cave Story. There is lots of ground to cover and lots of enemies to fight, so it's helpful that you'll get pretty well equipped over the course of the game. Quote, the robot you control, was built to use guns. Your first weaponry seems pretty pitiful, but when you kill enemies, they burst into glowing triangles which can be collected to power up the gun you're currently using. Hoover up a few of these gems and your polar star peashooter will become stronger! But, if you get hit, your weapons will lose that collected power and level down. It's important, then, to be aggressive and kill your enemies before you can get hit, but also to be careful and dodge attacks that are coming your way. You could even, if you're quick, swap to a weapon you won't use as much and let that one "take the hit", so to speak, keeping your most used weapons at max level. Bosses in this game are really memorable. There's a recurrent fight with one of the Doctor's cronies, a big lunkhead named Balrog. He's kinda cute, really - loyal to the wrong side, but probably with a good heart deep down. It's fun to beat him and hear him threaten to get you next time. There's a fight against an odd machine, stamped with glowing paw prints, and controlled by...something unexpected. The boss fights will tax you as a player, but Cave Story has generous checkpointing so if you are defeated, you won't have to travel far to try again. On that note, I have a criticism. Exploration is great, and there's lots in this game, but there's some areas - I'm looking at you Grasstown - which have far too much backtracking. Grasstown sees you collecting items to make a bomb, and one ingredient has to be collected no less than three times, requiring some serious repetition on the part of the player. This feels like padding, which really isn't necessary in a game which has so much varied content to see. It's a slight concern, really, nothing major, but it has frustrated me when I've tried to replay this game ("Ohhh, not this part again!") Another problem I have is the hoops you have to jump through to access the optional and more difficult end-game content. It requires skipping certain items and doing certain things out of a logical sequence, and honestly you're extremely unlikely to figure it out without resorting to a guide. Even having done it before many times, I still get it wrong because there are lets of steps to it and it isn't signposted anywhere in the game.This version of the game is Cave Story+. It's the same game, so still brilliant, but with redone music and visuals, the obligatory Steam achievements and trading cards and whatnot. I'll be honest and say that I don't think the New or Remastered music is much cop compared to the original, but you can opt to have whichever one you want. Same with the visuals. Don't like them? Set it back to the original art, wonderful as it is.You may ask, why would I get this version over the free version which is still floating around online?Controller support is one reason. I know lots of us are using XBOX360 pads and they are supported instantly, with no faffing, although ideally you'd want to use a controller with a better d-pad. You can jury rig the freeware version to support controllers, but it'll take extra software and a bit more legwork on the part of the player.The second and most important reason is that, by buying it, you're putting money in Pixel's pocket. He worked on this game for many years out of sheer passion, and decided to give it away for free for many more years, and I think that we should reward such generosity. He deserves a few quid thrown his way, and this game is often on sale, so you've no excuse.Cave Story is unmissable. It handles well, is attractive and sounds great, and actually has a really good story, with some legitimately terrific dialogue and characters. There may be frustrating moments where you'll struggle with a certain boss, or feel fatigued because you're retreading paths that you've been down before, but these are tiny blemishes on the surface of a diamond.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Everything about Cave Story hearkens back to the glory days of the SNES/Super Famicom. The lovingly hand-crafted graphics and catchy chiptune soundtrack create a vibrant "16 bit" environment. The storyline is interesting and quirky, with a distinctly Japanese flavor. Gameplay is somewhere between a "metroidvania" platformer and a "bullet hell" shoot-em-up: platforming challenges mix with a unique weapons upgrade system which rewards skillful dodging and punishes the slightest misstep with power-downs. There are certainly challenges to be had on higher difficulties, but those who just want to coast through the story will find options which suit them as well. Inconvenient save point locations can make difficult areas a bit of a grind, as you have to beat the same area over and over again to reach a boss fight or other difficult challenge, and the game does little other than drop hints to steer you towards your end goal. Perhaps the game's biggest flaw however is the length: a skilled gamer can breeze through easy difficulty in less than four hours. Certainly there is a lot of replayability, as one can increase the difficulty level or make different choices in storyline progression, but one must certainly have a strong appreciation for that type of repetition to endure.Overall Cave Story is a rewarding experience for gamers who yearn for secrets to discover, discrete clues, skill-based challenges, and the nostalgic thrill of it all being rendered in a faux 16-bit facade.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												This game is an extremely enjoyable Metroidvania that holds up as well as it did 12 years ago. Part of what makes this game a worthy investment of your time and money versus every other game on the market is that its not just good for an "indie" game, but that it is a professional quality game that merits comparison to games made by professional game developers. So many other indie games rely on visual gimmicks to sell their games that they sometimes forget that what really makes a good game is challenging and engaging gameplay. Cave Story has that in spades and its all the more amazing since it was made by one person.

content:
Posted: March 18
												Yo this game is Cave Story. Don't know if you've heard of it but it's been around forever and it's a real good, cute little platforming shooter.It's not all smiles and roses though. This particular port is busted on OSX and scaling is kind of a mess in Windows. Controllers sometimes don't register too. I also think the controls are too slippery to be a great platformer and I'm not a fan of how obscure the "good" endings and secrets are, you'll never find them without a guide.And maybe I just suck but I absolutely hate the structure of the final boss and how it has you doing four fights in a row with no saves or health refills between them and no way to completely skip dialog. Boy that gets old real fast.Still it's Cave Story and it's pretty good!

content:
Posted: February 6
												I can't decide if I love or hate this game, in all honesty. I love the story, music, characters, and the overall aesthetic of it. However, my beef with  Cave Story+  are the sudden,  highly  frustrating spikes in gameplay diifculty. I don't know, maybe it's just me, but there have been times in my playthrough where I have gotten stuck on a boss or area for--and I do not exaggerate--weeks or even  months  at a time. Either shooter-platformers aren't my thing, or there is something off about this. Don't let this stop you from buying it, though. Difficulty is not what kills a good game. The fact that I haven't thrown my computer off a cliff and cursed Studio Pixel's name to the four winds (though I have admittably gotten close) attests to this. I hear there's a free version somewhere, so maybe give that a try before spending money on this remastered version.Like my review? Check out my  Curator  page!

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												The game is a classic, and nothing I can say will deter the millions in love since it came out in 2004. I had never played this game until 2015--I didn't get into the Metroidvania genre as a kid. The purpose of mentioning this information is that (1) I didn't grow up with this classic, and (2) so many great games have come out, especialy within its genre, that, perhaps, my issue with the game is a problem with time. More specifically, the problem of genre saturation. Think of games like LIMBO that were the new standard of the puzzle-platformer, then those games were done over and over, and now, going back to LIMBO, the problems with the game stand more out as it's not as special as it once was.NES-styled games (or even Metroidvania games) are not that uncommon, nor are one-man projects--for example, Dust: An Eylsian Tale, Axiom Verge, Undertale, LISA etc.--as rare today. (I'm not saying the work has become easier. The novelty of one-man projects has come and gone.)Cave Story will continue to be an inspiration to many indie devs, and it earns its acclaim as a great game. No mistake was made there.However... I think some aspects, both of its gameplay and of its narrative, will stand out as time continues. And this is a review to newcomers so that you don't set too high expectations for the game. (There will be no spoilers.)Exploring the StoryFirst off, this game's story is almost too serious for how stupid it sounds on paper. And so many disturbing things that happen in game are quite dark when you think about the things you don't see. I love how absurd this story gets at times, but it also never forgets when to keep a straight face.The problem I have with this story is not what it is. My problem is how it is told, namely through exposition upon exposition, sometimes rather abruptly without any dramatic weight.I'm not against having complex plots or reading in my games. I love CRPGs after all. But this game loses all its mystique it builds up after the first hour as the game's story becomes told through constant expositions. Motives are sometimes introduced before you can imagine your own conclusions, and sometimes characters are suddenly introduced with a full backstory and the impact has no meaning.Not every exchange is telling you information for the sake of lore. The exchanges between Quote and Curly Brace feel heartwarming, and because I am invested in both characters the exposition doesn't come off as forced. There are also messages or notes hidden that share insight on characters, which is a great way to tell stories that feel like you made a discovery.More often this idea is a roadblock. For example, you get a character that is suddenly vital to the game's story without any foreshadowing or even a early mention, and his backstory is told while pausing the game (randomly) on the most difficult level. So not only is the story pulled out of nowhere it also gets in the way of the gameplay.It makes me wonder why not tell the exposition by other storytelling means like environmental design. The game has one or two moments like these, and on top of the notes/messages it feels like a reward for exploration.But that's enough to say on the story; it's small fish compared to the gameplay problems.Exploring the CaveFor a Metroidvania game, the game feels a little barebones in its mechanics. You get seven weapons with different arcs and effects as you level them up from collecting triangles (and you lose the XP by being constantly hit), but manyfeel worthless except for specific cases (the Fireball especially). You also get a jetpack, but not until two-thirds of the game is finished--I don't think there's a way to collect it early because, for a Metroidvania game, it's very linear. And the only items to collect are health upgrades. The one gamplay feature that I do like is the hidden difficulty throughout most of the game. You can swap out weapons or items to make earlier sections easier, or you can bite the bullet and earn the reward later. These aren't really obvious, and you won't know you made a bad decision until much later, which some of them tie into the bonus endings of the game. (There are really only two endings with a third one being a mid-game end. You will need a guide to know how to get the final/good ending because the game asks you to do something illogical). I really do like this feature because it ties so well into the heroic story where you influence the ones you can save and the people you simply cannot. These choices mean something.The overall difficulty is not a fair game. Save spots are frequent through most of the game, which you will want to save often because cutscenes will be replayed upon death without a skip option. Only the boss-rush at the end, and the final level with five bosses have one save spot. There are no E-tank substitutes--only a one-time full-health drink--but, like Megaman, you can kill smaller enemies in the boss-fights for health, weapon XP and missles. It takes real effort to regain your health in boss-fights, which I think is fine for when you have scattered save places. I would like that to be a player option rather than mandatory with the end-game'ssudden difficulty spike. And then you have the the last level. Symbolizing only one thing: Hell. (You will need a guide to trigger this outcome--no joke.) Either you will break your controller or you will develop a sixth sense of a bullet-hell mess for the level. Then you have to fight five boss-forms in ONE life, and if you fail you have to start all the way from the bullet-hell level. It feels like an excuse for NES difficulty rather than an actual challenge (and it reminds me too much of Street Fighter 2010: The Final Fight).And then you have extra challenge modes and a hard mode for enthusiasts. I might do a Curley Brace mode playthrough just for dialogue changes and for the normal ending. So, thankfully, for a short game (4 to 5 hours on a normal playthrough) there is lots of replay value for sadists.There's Still A Great Game To Be FoundPlease don't let my nitpicks convince you that this game is not worth the effort. Despite the steep difficulty curve, the game is very enjoyable and I can easily recommend it. All I want to say is just know what to expect: Don't let nostalgia keep the faults unseen because without knowing where we err we cannot know where we need to grow.

												Это отличная игра за свои деньги и лучшая в этом жанре из тех, в которые я играл.Плюсы:Оригинальная идея с опытом. Это единственная игра, в которой я намного больше следил за уровнем, чем за здоровьем (за ним вообще не следил, если честно, так что было много глупых смертей ради опыта).Тонна секретов. Я не нашёл ни один серьёзный секрет, хоть и осмотрел все углы в большинстве уровней.3 концовки (сразу предупрежу, что хорошую без гайда почти невозможно получить, так что готовьтесь к очень грустным и неоправданным событиям).Отличный баланс между стрельбой и платформером (но стрельбы всё равно больше, особенно в конце игры). Обычно в подобных играх всё время надоедают однообразные прыжки по платформам, либо однообразное мочилово, тут же я всю игру прошёл, даже немного не теряя интереса.Разные уровни сложности, что редко встречается в платформерах.Хороший сандутрек.Выбор между новой и старой графикой и музыкой.Минусы:Чтобы получить хорошую концовку, нужно сделать не очень логичное действие, а после этого тщательно подумать в одном месте. Ну или воспользоваться гайдом.Некоторые задания заставляют ходить по одной и той же локации кругами. На лёгкой сложности это не было проблемой, но на средней это ад.Очень маленькое разрешение. Мне это совершенно не помешало, но я представляю, как это должно быть ужасно для людей с 4К.Эта игра на лёгком закончилась всего за 4 часа, но смогла вызвать лёгкую депрессию. Слишком впечатлительным лучше не играть.P.S. Оригинальная игра бесплатна. Здесь лишь новая музыка, новые текстурки и несколько бесполезных фич. Но в оригинале Мимиги не такие милые, так что советую купить.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2013
												Cave Story is a game with an interesting history. Made by Daisuke "Pixel" Amaya this game was first released in 2004, later rereleased on Wii, DSi, Steam, and even 3DS. Cave Story takes heavy inspiration from games like Metroid and Castlevania. Only MUCH more fast and action-packed. This game has plenty to offer to casual and hardcore gamers alike. I think the most impressive thing about this game is that it's still so entertaining a decade later.             Like I said, this game is very fast and action-packed, with plenty of weapons designed for different situations. This game features a very simple leveling mechanic that (most of the time) makes your weapons stronger when the level up, sometimes changing how the weapon works in some way or another, while getting damaged can level down the weapon, making it fairly risky to rush the enemy.             There are plenty of unlockables in this game, from pointless items made as a joke (like finding one of the main character's panties) to new weapons that offer a whole new style of play. On top of that, there are bonus levels, time attack modes, boss rush modes, and even two very difficult secret areas, and a secret ending that was so satisfying to get.             If I could, I would go back to play this game for the first time again. With a very interesting, immersive story, great level design and pixel art, and one of the best soundtracks for an indie game, Cave Story+ gets a 10/10 from me.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												This game is fantastic! Well worth the money at any price. For starters, many of you have probably played this game for free in the past. This was a freeware game long ago, and this is the best known indy game of all time. Now before you say anything, it is worth the money, and this version is so much better than the free version.The game has 3 different soundtracks, (original, remastered, new), modes of play, (story, challenge), and two art styles (original and new). This game comes with the original soundtrack and visuals that look like the NES days of 8-bit. There is also a newer art style that is "HD" polished look, cleaner lines etc. 3D characters etc. The soundtrack from the original is there in all its glory. There is also a remastered version of the original soundtrack, and a brand new soundtrack. There are 3 saves slots in story mode, so you can mix and match art styles and soundtracks. I love this game, is tough, has questing, platforming, amazing boss fights, retro visuals and great gameplay. This is the best Cave Story version in my opinion.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Wowza, ok, first off I will let you know that Cave Story is simply put one of the best games of all time. In my top 25 games ever and it was made by just one dude, Daisuke Amaya. I will also let you know there is a freeware version available that is perfectly solid. Don't be afraid to play that version, because it's the original and it is of high quality. Previously I've beaten the freeware OS X version (the first time I beat it), then I beat the Windows version, then I beat the WiiWare version, and now I am on my fourth playthrough with CS+.CS + includes a variety of extras, new "HD" graphics, new OST, be sure to check between the new & old to see which you prefer.Buy it sometime.A+

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												An adorable game at sugar-high inducing levels of cuteness, it also provides a shockingly (at least, shockingly next to all the cuteness) dark setting underneath. While the silent protagonist is quite overdone by Japanese style games, it's still interesting to see the exchanges between characters and whatnot. The gameplay itself is nice. In the midst of all the 3D games, it's nice to have a 2D sidescroller once in a while, and it's quite reminiscent of games such as Metroid or whatnot. It's unique in that you have different levels for the weapons that you can lose by being hit (so there's encouragement to avoid attacks beyond hp) and gained by eating doritos. The gameplay mainly speaks more for itself, in any case. Also, the gameplay strikes a nice balance with difficulty. It becomes extremely difficult at times, but not overwhelmingly so. Of course, if you want to go for best ending... heh. Good luck.So, it's worth a try at least. Hell, the original is free if you don't want to spend $ or £ or whatever, though + refines the cuteness.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2013
												Ah, Cave Story. I remeber getting the demo of this on my Wii some time ago, and i enjoyed it. When i saw this on Steam i bought it as soon as i could. And i love this game. The game is like a good old 2D shooter, but the music and the RPG elements makes it different. I highly recommend using a controller to play, for convinience that is. The game is funny at times and i have cracked a smile once in a while. The game is however difficult, so difficult at times that i just had to put my controller down. The game does have the "What do i do and where do i go" moments in it, which really irritated me. The game is cheap and it gives more than it costs. If you ever see this on sale or have some spare money in your steam wallet, buy it! It's worth it.

												I'd almost call this a classic game by now. I like to play it again at times (mostly on another device, though). The controls are solid. The gameplay is fun and challenging, but definitely not too hard (except the one mode without health containers. I mean, what the hell? How?!)The backtracking can get annoying sometimes, but I can't recall bothering at all the first time I played the game.A little hint from my side: Change the option about the music to the original music, not the remastered music. It is so much better in my opinion. But who knows? Your taste might be different, and I respect that.

												A fantastic remake of an already brilliant game. They kept all the hardcore gamers in mind (the ones who played the original one by Daisuke "Pixel" Amaya) and allowed them to switch on the old graphics with the old music; that's not to say that the new graphics and new music is bad, but they clearly thought this remake through, very well. The game itself is brilliant and a hallmark of early indie games history of the current generation. An absolute must have.

content:

												It's hard for me to explain the joy this game brought to me when I first played through it as a Doukutsu Monogatari (洞窟物語) as freeware.Buying this game to support Mr. Daisuke Amaya (Pixel) is a great pleasure, and I hope that other people find it in their hearts to buy this game as well.This game is an updated version of the original Cave Story (which can still be downloaded for free) that features: Full official translation. The choice of using updated sprites and music (as well as the original music remastered on PC/Mac).Extra modes and secrets.I will be hard-pressed to offer another platformer that offers the same depth Cave Story does, and the easiest way to recommend this game is to simply play the original version and be inspired to purchase this game.[www.cavestory.org]Another wonderful game by Mr. Amaya, that is also free.[www.cavestory.org]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Cave Story never stops being a gem - you can argue this for many different reasons. I mean, sure the soundtrack is amazing and the gameplay is genius in its seemingly simplistic nature. If this game just had that going for it, it'd simply be a good game.Then you dig deeper into the game and start to find the minutae of it's genius. Its indie charm resonates even deeper when you realize that this game (arguably) began the indie craze. It's constructed, top-to-bottom, by a single individual over many years of hard work and dedication. How Pixel found the time to create a surprisingly deep, and shocking, narrative is another matter entirely.This game is impressive in every way a game can be. I'll never stop enjoying it no matter how many times I play it, and completely recommend you give it a whirl.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												This game is fantastic! Well worth the money at any price. For starters, many of you have probably played this game for free in the past. This was a freeware game long ago, and this is the best known indy game of all time. Now before you say anything, it is worth the money, and this version is so much better than the free version.The game has 3 different soundtracks, (original, remastered, new), modes of play, (story, challenge), and two art styles (original and new). This game comes with the original soundtrack and visuals that look like the NES days of 8-bit. There is also a newer art style that is "HD" polished look, cleaner lines etc. 3D characters etc. The soundtrack from the original is there in all its glory. There is also a remastered version of the original soundtrack, and a brand new soundtrack. There are 3 saves slots in story mode, so you can mix and match art styles and soundtracks. I love this game, is tough, has questing, platforming, amazing boss fights, retro visuals and great gameplay. This is the best Cave Story version in my opinion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												I'm sort of biased about this game.I say this because I played it before it was on Steam. As a freeware PC game, it was top notch. Hard to believe the original was made by just 1 guy. However, this isn't the original release I'm reviewing and they charge 14.99 for this version.The game itself is some sort of a strange hybrid of Run N' Gun platforming mixed with Metroidvania, as the whole game is just 1 huge level with some backtracking is required to obtain certain items.The controls themselves are excellent and there is a nice variety of different weapons you can use. Also, the minimalistic graphics and chiptune soundtrack give the game a unique retro vibe which is either hit-or-miss, depending on whether you like 8 bit games. The game does come with 2 graphic modes and 3 versions of the soundtrack though, so you can adjust the feel of the game somewhat if you feel inclined to.At about a third through the game, following a plot twist, the game starts gaining momentum. The plot becomes darker, the bactracking becomes a lot less common, your arsenal starts growing to a nice size, and the game becomes a joy to play, with more varied environments, more challenging enemies, and epic boss battles.My main issue with the game is it's first third. During your first few hours of the game, your arsenal is very limited, you backtrack through the same environments over and over on fetch quests, and fight the same enemies. This part of the game greatly highlights it's low budget and repeatedly recycled assets. However, if you endure enough to get over this frustrating part of the game, you're in for a treat as the following parts of the game are excellent.Another minor gripe I have with the game is how easy it is to miss the best ending. The game has 4 endings (same as the original), and getting the best one will probably require a guide, as reaching it is very unintuitive and much harder to do than any of the others.I have a problem recommending this one. As much as I love the later parts of the game, this Steam release doesn't really add much content, and the earlier segments of the game might make you lose interest before you get to the good parts. I recommend you try the original, free version, as it's basically the same game without some modern conveniences. If you enjoy that one, like I did, and a higher resolution, new soundtrack, and an additional level justify the 15$ for you, I say go for it.

												Cave Story is one of the original indie dev success stories, and there's no surprise as to why it's so successful. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2012
												An indie game that structurally started said movement of the, "too deep for you," nonsense that has plagued the majority of indie games alike, consider me surprised when I played it and found it to be amazing.Gameplay follows a metroidvania element, with environments stemming towards a free-flowing and fluid design that goes heavenly with the soft and twitchy movements that Quote can do. It contrasts a bit, further on, as you obtain the Jetpack, for it breaks the foundation that you maintained for so long, yet the game still makes it able to be introduced to where complications with it aren't lived for too long.The story follows a set example of amnesia-cased shenanigans, which develops, with the implications and the history provided, into a depressing set of acts that can be only described as brilliant, once acknowledged. The music fits to the criteria with every given situation, and gives an impact through the gameplay itself that makes it so that actions blend well with the mood of the environment, which gives the player a better understanding of the story without using cutscenes and text to remotely convey it whatsoever. The graphics themselves are sprites of olde time, but alongside the music, adds a vibrant flavor to them that seals the deal, throughout it all.Although a free version exists, the creator deserves the money for what he has accomplished with such a cute game. It is certainly quite the story, that's for sure.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Game: Cave Story+Genre: AdventureDeveloper: Studio PixelSystem: PC (Steam)Total Score: 83/100Value Score: 8.3/10• Story: 8/10o You play as a robot called "Quote" who wakes up suddenly in a mysterious cave. You learn that a race of creatures called Mimiga exist in the island of the cave you are in. You have no memory of who or what you are but you explore through the mysterious cave and eventually find out that a mysterious group of people are planning to use the island as a basis to take over the outside world. As you go through the different locations of the island, learning the mysteries of the island and its denizens and traversing through monster infested caves you learn a dark hidden secret under the island.• Characters: 9/10o Cave Story+ has a colorful cast of characters of all sorts of kinds such as robots, mimigas (creatures in the game), humans, goblin like beings, talking roaches, dogs, little people and many other types of beings. You play as a robot named Quote who seems to have some sort of tie to the past of the island and you eventually meet or find of your kind. The enemy designs in the game is quite well done and are original for the most part. Very rarely do you see a similar sprite enemy with a alternate color and all the NPC type characters you come across are all noticeable different with each of them having a unique personality sometimes reflecting of the modern world.• GamePlay: 8/10o Cave Story+ is a platformer RPG like shooter. You have a health based system which you can increase if you find health capsules/containers, you also get a variety of different types of weapons all of which are projectile type weapons and has long range uses depending on what level they are. You can gain levels for your weapons after collecting little triangle bit looking pieces which count as EXP. Some weapons benefit from gaining a level while others get weaker. You also get a set of different items most of which are key items which is usable only through a storyline event and some are additional power ups which are optional. You'll be going through caves and all sorts of locations fighting off all sorts of different types of enemies whether they are in the water, air or land. Just like a platformer you have the ability to jump across platforms, enemies or to get to a certain area along with the fact that you can power up your jump through a upgrade. Cave Story+ is somewhat difficult and can get more difficult depending on what setting you used to start with or with what paths you take the game as you can get multiple endings and ending results depending on some of the decisions you make that will affect your overall gameplay experience as well. There's also a challenge option where you can go in and have time challenges which can also be recorded.• Graphics: 8/10o Cave Story+ uses a unique 2D style art design and gameplay visual which will shoot rays of nostalgia at the player especially if the player has been playing games since they were primarily 2D. The PC version looks far more refined than the other versions of the game. Each character, object, and environment area looks unique from each other so dont expect it to get repetitive to the point where you will be bored. However due to the fact of the way it was developed, your choice on resolution may be limited as it is possible that black borders may take up the left and right of the actual game screen.• Sound: 7/10o If you play a side scroll shooter or any of the old school games from the 1980s or the early 1990s you will understand how the sound effects are like. There are a lot of nostalgic like sound effects which sound similar to different aspects from different games of the old times. Although there isnt voiceovers the creators of the game did a nice notion of adding a sound effect when a character talks although all the NPCs you talk to sound the same in that instance.• Music: 10/10o Cave Story+'s OST is an amazingly well done soundtrack which has the 8-bit tone of what you would consider techno/metal/orchestral music of the old gaming eras. Each area of the game has a unique track and there are unique boss battle themes depending on what kind of boss you are fighting whether it is the final boss, a mini boss or a actual boss. You will surely enjoy the classical 8-bit like OST. You also have the option to change the OST to the classic original style.• Length: 7/10o Cave Story+ is consisted of mostly a linear path which takes you to around 5-6 general areas with some small areas between each other. You also have the choice of making a decision which can alter the length of the game. However the game should not take you more than 15 hours to complete unless you die a lot or get lost.• Replay Value: 8/10o Cave Story+ uses a multi-ending style for its storyline, depending on the decisions you make you can change the game's outcome. There are about three different endings, one of which you can get when you finish the game halfway across, the second one which is the general ending and a third ending which is considered the best ending providing you accomplish certain tasks or did certain events in a certain way. You also have challenges which allow you to play through speed like stages where you are timed and can be recorded. You can also play the game again with multiple difficulties. The gameplay experience also changes depending on what you chose in the game as your weapon or again what certain paths you have taken or avoided.• Player Value: 8/10o Cave Story+ is a pretty good 2D platformer which takes elements and aspects from different types of other genres such as shooters, RPG and action games. The game has a sarcastic eastern tone to it with a few internet meme references along with the fact that the game uses audio and a art style which was common in the 1980s and 1990s but is unique now. The game's storyline and characters will make you enjoy your experience along with the sheer difficulty some of the levels and areas of the game will bring to you. Get this game on Steam while it is hot with the price it will be depending if its summer or winter. You will not regret the purchase of this game at all.

												Wowza, ok, first off I will let you know that Cave Story is simply put one of the best games of all time. In my top 25 games ever and it was made by just one dude, Daisuke Amaya. I will also let you know there is a freeware version available that is perfectly solid. Don't be afraid to play that version, because it's the original and it is of high quality. Previously I've beaten the freeware OS X version (the first time I beat it), then I beat the Windows version, then I beat the WiiWare version, and now I am on my fourth playthrough with CS+.CS + includes a variety of extras, new "HD" graphics, new OST, be sure to check between the new & old to see which you prefer.Buy it sometime.A+

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												An adorable game at sugar-high inducing levels of cuteness, it also provides a shockingly (at least, shockingly next to all the cuteness) dark setting underneath. While the silent protagonist is quite overdone by Japanese style games, it's still interesting to see the exchanges between characters and whatnot. The gameplay itself is nice. In the midst of all the 3D games, it's nice to have a 2D sidescroller once in a while, and it's quite reminiscent of games such as Metroid or whatnot. It's unique in that you have different levels for the weapons that you can lose by being hit (so there's encouragement to avoid attacks beyond hp) and gained by eating doritos. The gameplay mainly speaks more for itself, in any case. Also, the gameplay strikes a nice balance with difficulty. It becomes extremely difficult at times, but not overwhelmingly so. Of course, if you want to go for best ending... heh. Good luck.So, it's worth a try at least. Hell, the original is free if you don't want to spend $ or £ or whatever, though + refines the cuteness.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Game: Cave Story+Genre: AdventureDeveloper: Studio PixelSystem: PC (Steam)Total Score: 83/100Value Score: 8.3/10• Story: 8/10o You play as a robot called "Quote" who wakes up suddenly in a mysterious cave. You learn that a race of creatures called Mimiga exist in the island of the cave you are in. You have no memory of who or what you are but you explore through the mysterious cave and eventually find out that a mysterious group of people are planning to use the island as a basis to take over the outside world. As you go through the different locations of the island, learning the mysteries of the island and its denizens and traversing through monster infested caves you learn a dark hidden secret under the island.• Characters: 9/10o Cave Story+ has a colorful cast of characters of all sorts of kinds such as robots, mimigas (creatures in the game), humans, goblin like beings, talking roaches, dogs, little people and many other types of beings. You play as a robot named Quote who seems to have some sort of tie to the past of the island and you eventually meet or find of your kind. The enemy designs in the game is quite well done and are original for the most part. Very rarely do you see a similar sprite enemy with a alternate color and all the NPC type characters you come across are all noticeable different with each of them having a unique personality sometimes reflecting of the modern world.• GamePlay: 8/10o Cave Story+ is a platformer RPG like shooter. You have a health based system which you can increase if you find health capsules/containers, you also get a variety of different types of weapons all of which are projectile type weapons and has long range uses depending on what level they are. You can gain levels for your weapons after collecting little triangle bit looking pieces which count as EXP. Some weapons benefit from gaining a level while others get weaker. You also get a set of different items most of which are key items which is usable only through a storyline event and some are additional power ups which are optional. You'll be going through caves and all sorts of locations fighting off all sorts of different types of enemies whether they are in the water, air or land. Just like a platformer you have the ability to jump across platforms, enemies or to get to a certain area along with the fact that you can power up your jump through a upgrade. Cave Story+ is somewhat difficult and can get more difficult depending on what setting you used to start with or with what paths you take the game as you can get multiple endings and ending results depending on some of the decisions you make that will affect your overall gameplay experience as well. There's also a challenge option where you can go in and have time challenges which can also be recorded.• Graphics: 8/10o Cave Story+ uses a unique 2D style art design and gameplay visual which will shoot rays of nostalgia at the player especially if the player has been playing games since they were primarily 2D. The PC version looks far more refined than the other versions of the game. Each character, object, and environment area looks unique from each other so dont expect it to get repetitive to the point where you will be bored. However due to the fact of the way it was developed, your choice on resolution may be limited as it is possible that black borders may take up the left and right of the actual game screen.• Sound: 7/10o If you play a side scroll shooter or any of the old school games from the 1980s or the early 1990s you will understand how the sound effects are like. There are a lot of nostalgic like sound effects which sound similar to different aspects from different games of the old times. Although there isnt voiceovers the creators of the game did a nice notion of adding a sound effect when a character talks although all the NPCs you talk to sound the same in that instance.• Music: 10/10o Cave Story+'s OST is an amazingly well done soundtrack which has the 8-bit tone of what you would consider techno/metal/orchestral music of the old gaming eras. Each area of the game has a unique track and there are unique boss battle themes depending on what kind of boss you are fighting whether it is the final boss, a mini boss or a actual boss. You will surely enjoy the classical 8-bit like OST. You also have the option to change the OST to the classic original style.• Length: 7/10o Cave Story+ is consisted of mostly a linear path which takes you to around 5-6 general areas with some small areas between each other. You also have the choice of making a decision which can alter the length of the game. However the game should not take you more than 15 hours to complete unless you die a lot or get lost.• Replay Value: 8/10o Cave Story+ uses a multi-ending style for its storyline, depending on the decisions you make you can change the game's outcome. There are about three different endings, one of which you can get when you finish the game halfway across, the second one which is the general ending and a third ending which is considered the best ending providing you accomplish certain tasks or did certain events in a certain way. You also have challenges which allow you to play through speed like stages where you are timed and can be recorded. You can also play the game again with multiple difficulties. The gameplay experience also changes depending on what you chose in the game as your weapon or again what certain paths you have taken or avoided.• Player Value: 8/10o Cave Story+ is a pretty good 2D platformer which takes elements and aspects from different types of other genres such as shooters, RPG and action games. The game has a sarcastic eastern tone to it with a few internet meme references along with the fact that the game uses audio and a art style which was common in the 1980s and 1990s but is unique now. The game's storyline and characters will make you enjoy your experience along with the sheer difficulty some of the levels and areas of the game will bring to you. Get this game on Steam while it is hot with the price it will be depending if its summer or winter. You will not regret the purchase of this game at all.

												Reminiscent of old-school Metroid or Castlevania games, this is an extremely fun game and gets very challenging in the later stages without becoming too frustrating. The system that has your weapons leveling up as enemies fall and losing levels when damage is taken adds a nice strategic depth (as a boss might hit you one too many times and render your favorite weapon almost worthless). The story is also very well-written and does a good job of immersing you in the game world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2011
												When the original Cave Story was released on the PC, it gained rave reviews. Harkening back to the era of the (N)th bit adventure games (where "N" is a number), it reminded us of those classic sidescrolling games of yester year: the Castlevanias and the Metroids, and so on.Now, it gets a proper PC release, and it is worth every penny. Cave Story is a side scrolling adventure game, in the same vein as the Metroidvania games I talked about. Yet now it's got upgraded graphics and remasterd music.Essentially, it's the Wii version, but in higher definition. Don't let that fact put you off though, it's still a great game that will make you yearn for more adventure once you're finished with this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												I first played Cave Story when it was a Japanese freeware game with a fan translation, probably around 2005 or so. It wss a great game then, and Cave Story+ is perhaps better.The game itself is a solid platformer, challenging, yet fair. The story is decent; by no means stellar, but not bad either. Cave Story+ adds graphical and musical improvements to the original, as well as additiona game modes, challenges, and difficulty settings. Additionally, there is the option to use the original graphics and music, so fans of the original can still play it as such. All in all, A solid game worth giving a playthrough or two.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2012
												Cave Story is arguably the most well known indie games in the world, as well as one of my personal favorites. Play as Quote, a robotic soldier who awakens on a mysterious island floating through the sky, on his epic quest to save the Mimigas, a race of rabbit like creatures, from the clutches of an evl Doctor who is mad with power.... But on  his journey, Quote discovers that the Doctor was nothing compared to the TRUE evil that lies within. Join Quote in this touching story as he strives to save the island, find his past, and defete the evil doctor.Cave Story by Nicilas "Pixel", Studio Pixel.Rated E10 for Mild Language, and Mild Cartoon Violence

												이 게임의 특징은 개발자인 "Pixel"씨가 다년간 혼자 공들여 만든 수작게임이라는 것입니다. 사실 케이브 스토리는 제가 스팀 마켓에 출시되기 전부터 이 게임이 스팀에 올라오면 얼마나 좋을까 하고 상상해 왔던 게임입니다. 보통 세일하면 사는 세일족인 제가 출시되고 기념 10% 할인밖에 안하는데 냉큼 질렀었던 기억이 나네요, 레트로풍의 플렛폼 게임의 정석이자 교과서 같은 게임입니다. 스토리도 괜찮고 음악도 나쁘지 않습니다. 처음엔 이걸 뭐하러 몇번씩 들이나 깨지 라고 생각하시겠지만 결국 자연스럽게 몇회차 플레이도 하게 되는 자신을 보게 되실지도 몰라요. 지인들에게도 몇번 사준 기억이 납니다. 추천하고 싶은 게임입니다

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Did you know Cave Story was made by one man? To be honest, you probably did, but if not, you should be impressed.I enjoyed this game a LOT, my hours should pretty much be the evidence for that. The gameplay is pretty addicting, it isn't easy, but not too hard either (for the most part, atleast).However, the original version of the game - found at http://www.cavestory.org/ - is free and it's pretty much the same with the exception of challenges and runs at 50fps, while the Cave Story+ version runs at 60fps. As a player of both versions, I got to say, I enjoyed the CS+ version more.If you don't like the "remastered" graphics or soundtrack you can always change them to original (in the soundtrack, there's a "New" version, which is the Wii version's music, I believe).Beware, though, there IS one achievement that is bugged, and as having all other achievements, this is annoying and makes me wish Nicalis fixed it.For some reason, I didn't really enjoy it at the start (stopped at around the 2nd or 3rd area), but once I got around to play it again, I enjoyed it.Rating? It's a solid 9/10 for me, there were some annoying parts that otherwise would make this a 10/10.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												A lot of people says this is comparable to metroid, megaman, or whatever. Since I was never familiar with any of those games, I came into this one completely blind. All I have to say is that this game is absolutely great, and certainly a decent stepping stone for those who never impored the mentioned games.Most of my experience comes from the freeware version (since I had no idea I had a code for this in a old humble bundle I got some years ago) but I did dabble in this game for a good chunk and it's quite great. The gameplay is easy to understand, The control is responsive and smooth, a good amount of weapons to use and experiment with, different endings, and a good sense of challenge and difficulty within the main game. Let's not talk about the good ending doe...The extras this port provides is great too, such as the option to play as another protagonist and which version of graphics/sounds you'd like to use. It definitely adds to the value. I do suggest you try the freeware version at cavestory.org first, but this port is definitely worth a purchase (even at full price) if you liked what you played.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
 Cave Story review I'm playing Cave Story since 2013 with more than 10 playthroughs and I have played the 3DS (including the remake that i'm not going to talk about in this review), Wii and Pc versions. All three versions are good, and have exclusive content like 3DS having 3DS, but my favorite version is the Cave Story+ for pc because you have sprites and music improvement, but you can still choose the original ones, some extra modes, playing with keyboard or controller and specially what makes this version the best it's the achievements. I conclusion I can recommend you to play the original cave story series.Do not play cave story 3D the original one is much better Cave Story+ review Just talking about the steam version, that I had played already 24.7hours and cleared already sometimes, I can recommend you to play this version if you are a pc gamer and like to play with keyboard.Differences between versions.Cave story + 3 save slots extra modes achievementsOriginal one 1 save slot you just can play on normal diff.  FREE (0$) Rating   Category rate   Graphics 9   music 8   story 9   Controlls 7.5   overall 8.5 I really like cave story. The graphics are old school but clean,beautiful and amazing for a 2004 game. I can't talk that much about the music and sound effects because I'm not too much into this kind of stuff : | but I can say that the story is really deep and good, prepare to cry (jk). The cons of the game are the controlls that aren't the best (but not bad too, but the controlls could be better) and some achievements are broken, the hell one I think. Final wordsIf you like 2D games, metroidvania and hard games then this game is for you! Just buy it or download the free version to try it!!

												Cave Story is arguably the most well known indie games in the world, as well as one of my personal favorites. Play as Quote, a robotic soldier who awakens on a mysterious island floating through the sky, on his epic quest to save the Mimigas, a race of rabbit like creatures, from the clutches of an evl Doctor who is mad with power.... But on  his journey, Quote discovers that the Doctor was nothing compared to the TRUE evil that lies within. Join Quote in this touching story as he strives to save the island, find his past, and defete the evil doctor.Cave Story by Nicilas "Pixel", Studio Pixel.Rated E10 for Mild Language, and Mild Cartoon Violence

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												An incredibly robust example of a simple, yet entirely engaging side scrolling action-adventure game. Don't let the simplicity of the mechanics and initial plot get to you- this game is an amazing example of the genre. If you're a fan of Metroid or Castlevania, you'll love this piece.Did I mention the original version of this game was done by only one person? Yeah. Everything. The game engine, graphics, story, music, everything. Even if the length of the game doesn't impress you compared to others of its genre, keep that factoid in mind. With that, I certainly don't regret buying this game on two different ports.
