content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Cave Story is a pixilated shooter, platformer, and adventure game made by Daisuke Amaya (Pixel) who spent five years working on this masterpiece and is based off of a famous game made by Nintendo known as Metroid. It has beautiful 8-bit graphics, a great soundtrack, an amazing story, and is a game you must play if you like Metroid.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												If you're interested, and you think the game is too expensive then you have got to download the free version! Cave Story was originally created by one guy, who spent over five years trying to make the game amazing and something that he himself would enjoy. The gameplay is a ton of fun, and the physics have a great feel if you like 2D plaformers. It's very satisfying to jump around and shoot things, especially since the weapons themselves are unique and creative. The music is some of the best I've heard in a video game. It makes you want to make your character dance around as it dodges bullets, and even inspires you to complete the hardest trial as you literally travel through hell. This version of Cave Story has three soundtracks to choose from, so make sure try them out in the options (my favourite is the original). The story is pretty good, but I think the writing in the fan translation was done better. The game's difficulty has a nice curve I think, it can get really quite challenging but still not unfair. Even if a boss is too hard causing you to take a break, or even if you beat the game; everyone I know who has enjoyed it, has come back to the game to beat the boss, or has replayed the game from the very start because it's simply just that fun. I played the original 7 or 8 years ago and still replay it today. As I've said before if you can't buy it, get the free version. Completely worth it. Did I mention there's a puppy saving quest where the puppies ride on your head? Yes!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Cave Story+ is a game I first picked up on my Nintendo DSi a few years back. After playing through it once again, I had to see what was different between the DS version and PC/Console version. I got the game on sale for around $10, and the game is definately worth the $10 I spent and more. Pros+Decently lengthed Story(6-8 Hours in my experience) +Multiple difficulties that are actually different(Easy, Medium, and Hard AKA Pain in yoour A$$)+Many distict areas with differing enemies+Interesting (and sometimes funny) weapons+Interesting and in depth characters that have personallity+Nice extra challanges that can de difficult for old players+Multiple endings baised on items obtained and actions takenCons-The area for the True ending, Hell, is incredibly difficult and takes hours of practice unless you have done it defore-Boss difficulty is a bit all over the place, one boss being really hard, the next easy, then super hard again-Some weapons have really odd or illusive ways to obtain them-Mimiga Village is confusing for first time players on where to go, which may cause them to unnessisarily search the entire town, or stumble into the right place in the first few secondsCave Story+ is an amazing game. Especially considering that it was made by one guy and was originally released in 2003. I have this game up on my list of favorites and can't stop recommending people to get it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												An absolute gem of a game.I was worried this would be one of those "ultra-hard" platformers like Super Meat Boy etc, which  are really not my thing.    Cave Story+ is not that.  What it is is a complete, fleshed out and polished platformer with a story, goals, the right amount of exploration and discovery.  Finished it on Easy (2 endings) which I found challenging enough, and although I know there is more content awaiting me on the harder difficulty modes, that is something better left to completionists and those with more free time and/or dexterity than I have.   A good 9 hours in to complete what I did and I'm very satisfied with the overall experience.The graphics are great in a polished, retro-way, and the music (remastered) was catchy and enjoyable.  Controls with a 360 controller were spot on.  I'm at a point where I prefer games to be on the shorter side (4-5 hours), but though I put double that into this it did not over-stay its welcome.    I was able to get through the harder areas after a few tries, and the generous amount of save points (with the possible exception of the 2nd ending sequences) kept me from repeating too much. Hint: save the life refill potion for that last bit!Those seeking more can try the other difficulty modes which add some content. There are also "score attack"-type challenges although they would not run properly for me, but those are not something I would go back to regardless.Overall, highly recommended to anyone who enjoys platformers with a retro-feel (but modern controls). It is certainly one of the better titles in my library.

Finished it on Easy (2 endings) which I found challenging enough, and although I know there is more content awaiting me on the harder difficulty modes, that is something better left to completionists and those with more free time and/or dexterity than I have.   A good 9 hours in to complete what I did and I'm very satisfied with the overall experience.The graphics are great in a polished, retro-way, and the music (remastered) was catchy and enjoyable.  Controls with a 360 controller were spot on.  I'm at a point where I prefer games to be on the shorter side (4-5 hours), but though I put double that into this it did not over-stay its welcome.    I was able to get through the harder areas after a few tries, and the generous amount of save points (with the possible exception of the 2nd ending sequences) kept me from repeating too much. Hint: save the life refill potion for that last bit!Those seeking more can try the other difficulty modes which add some content. There are also "score attack"-type challenges although they would not run properly for me, but those are not something I would go back to regardless.Overall, highly recommended to anyone who enjoys platformers with a retro-feel (but modern controls). It is certainly one of the better titles in my library.

content:
Posted: February 11
												Cave Story is one of the best designed games of all time. Every section of each level feels meticulously designed to guide the player and teach them. The game almost never explains anything with text boxes or standard tutorials, not even which buttons to press. But the game prefectly teaches you everything you have to know with subtle level design and graphics. There's a suprising amount of extra content for you to find and multiple endings, the hardest ending being one of the biggest challenges I've ever had playing a video game. There's a huge amount of boss battles and I never found myself being too annoyed by any enemies or bosses because of how fair they all were. A great example of being fair to the player is the fact that many enemies in the game won't deal damage when you touch them, they'll only deal damage to you during their attack animation. This is a great game with replay value, great art design, great level design, comfortable controls, and good music. There's not much I can think to critique about this game. Regardless of what kinds of games you like, you should play this game.

												The world's most popular doujin game. For good reason, too. This side-scrolling Metroidvania has you playing as Quote, an amnesiac robot who is trying to recover his memory while helping the island natives. The OST is wonderful, and in this version you can pick from remixes or the original chiptune songs, both of which are pretty damn good. Graphically, the updated visuals are nice, though being able to return to the original sprites and such was a very welcome addition. Cave Story lends itself well to replayability, with speed-running, time trials and various different endings and choices. I really can't recommend this game enough. This game's pretty damn fun. It's also oddly cozy, if you're into that.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												There's a plenty of reasons you should play this one, unless you are 100% into non-realtime or 3D games. First of all, this is the best re-release since the Doukutsu Monogatari was originally introduced in 2005 in Japanese only. Other ones lack some features or play differently.Being a "doujin" videogame, Cave Story predates all the indie mumbo jumbo that's so noisy nowadays. It was made by one person over the course of 5 years or so. The pixel art, the music, the engine, the audio subsystem with custom tracker-like format, all authored by "Pixel". But that's just the historical reason to get to know it.Gameplay-wise, Cave Story is a traditional platformer akin to Metroid, with role-playing elements. Unlike the old games of 90's, it is really long - I'd say 10 hours for a blindrun by an experienced player. More than that, you aren't going to have the Best Ending in the first run, and to get that one, you should either be very inquisitive, or know the story pivot point beforehand.Finally, I nominate this game for the "Test Of Time" Steam Award 2016.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												Cave Story is a game I admit I overlooked for some years, until a friend, who had suggested many a time that I should play it, decide to buy me this updated version. Thus, I was out of excuses.If you are unfamiliar with the game, as I was, it's a Metroidvania originally made by one Japanese guy over the course of five years. You begin a cave, with no items, no idea where to go, and no idea even who or what you are, and in true genre fashion, are expected to blunder about until you get your bearings. Or you could just use a guide, like I did.The game's overall presentation is cutesy and at times endearing. It reminds me of classic NES platformers in this way, as well as games that make you feel good about yourself like Kingdom Hearts and Shantae, though personally I think it could have taken a few pointers from the latter. The visuals and music were competent as well, but something about the entire asthetic never really clicked with me. It does make the rather heavy plot more impactful, out of dissonance, I think. I had no idea going in how important the story was to the experience, or that it would make care for a character like Curly Brace. A shame it punishes you so hard for caring, as I will touch on a bit later.Mechanically speaking, I have few complaints. New weapons and upgrades feel great, and complement each other almost flawlessly: Each weapon is adept at a certain combat scenario that the others aren't, and you almost always have a way of hitting enemies without taking unnecessary damage, unlike, say, Mercenary Kings. However, the jumping is a tad unresponsive and flight control is sluggish, and in particular inertia is strangely powerful for a game of this type. It's fortunate that the game has a minimum of deathtraps, at least early on, or I would have found myself sliding into them much more often. The game is on the short side for it's genre. though I'd hardly call that a shortcoming. It's also on the easy side, though It recommended I play easy mode as a first-time player, so I can hardly complain. And then the game descides to shove a difficulty spike up my♥♥♥♥♥ almost souring the entire experience for me. In the span of a single zone, the creator attempted to pack all the old school NES death course ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t he didn't include earlier on, culminating in a whooping FOUR phase boss fight with minimal opportunities to heal, and no checkpoint prior to the boss or between any phases, forcing you to repeat the entire course again if you die, and only giving you a single full health restore, one of two in the game, to use. It was the kind of level that doesn't feel satisfying even when you win. I can only hope that the cast had a happy life thereafter.I can't honestly recommend Cave Story to everyone, based on the punishing difficulty of this last level. The only alternative is the very obviously bad ending where you flee in shame, and who would do that? Unless you really want that achievement, I suppose. But if you thoroughly enjoy a challenge, or at least a good story, It is likely worth trying. Just don't say I never warned you.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Note: I've completed this game twice on the original PC version and twice on the DS version, now I'm going to attempt 100% on the Steam version.This game is my favourite game of all time, I've poured hours into it in the past, and I will be doing so again now and in the future. The soundtrack of this game remains my favourite, Pulse and Geothermal are my top two tracks, and I have the entire soundtrack on my phone to listen to sometimes. I play this game with the original music and visuals, because it feels nostalgic somehow, so I can't give much input into the remastered versions of the two. Curly is an awesome character, and genuinely pulls on your heart strings at times throughout the game, and all the other characters grow lovable too, even the villains. The gameplay is a mixture of megaman and castlevania, or better known as the genre 'metroidvania', which wouldn't usually appeal to me, but does somehow. There are a wide variety of weapons to find throughout the game, some requiring restarts of the game to get, since it's a pick-this-or-that type thing, which is fine because there's fairly good replayability, and plenty of achievements to get alongside your restarts.Probably 200+ hours of game time if you're dedicated to getting 100%, definitely worth the price, more so on sale. I more than recommend this game to anybody wanting a retro indie game with an amazing story, solid characters and a perfect soundtrack. 10/10 for sure, in my books.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Superb for its time and still pretty good by today's standards.Cave Story+ excels in many of the major categories you'd rate it in. It's written with a lot of wit and charm. The gameplay is fun with a wide range of weapons that give you a lot of utility. Level design is varied and keeps things interesting and challenging. The soundtrack is a nostalgic trip into chiptune goodness.It does have some flaws though. Its challenge mode is broken for me and many other players by crashing as soon as I reach the finish of the first challenge. Don't expect this to be patched as it's been known for a long time and nothing has been done about it. I'm also not impressed with its graphics. They're not terrible, in fact some of the character designs might be called cute, but many of the environments are drab mixes of grays and browns. I generally found the soundtrack catchy but there were a few tunes that became annoying. Playing on "original" difficulty I thought that the combat had a satisfying level of challenge to it. However, the amount of damage you take from environmental dangers like spikes was too harsh in my view. There are numerous traps that will kill you in one shot no matter how much health you have. That is more unforgiving than I like, especially in a game with slightly floaty controls. Fortunately, the controls are consistent throughout the game so you can adapt to them and they become more manageable once you get the booster. Keeping with the old school  theme you are unable to shoot diagonally, only in the four cardinal directions.I'd like to close by bringing special attention to the rich world that is explored in Cave Story+. There's a fascinating backstory to discover as you play as well as fun characters to interact with. As with most "Metroidvania" games there are plenty of hidden and optional areas but here you won't just find power-ups. There are side quests, additional lore, optional weapons and gear, and even events that can lead to different endings for the game. This is a dream for players that love to dig into all the details of a game.

												Great game!But it's free if you know how to google.I stick to the stupid purist idea that you should play this game on at least original music, if you don't go wholly into original everything for cave story.The skill ramp is somewhat perfect with little deviation,And the game has a great story with multiple endings, (with the true ending being arguably impossible to naturally achieve on your first playthrough without a guide.)Don't be an idiot, don't pay 15 for it, but buy and play it nonetheless.Extra: This creator of this game created this in his spare time over 4 years. He also created a music-creating software for this game and another game called Ika-Chan. (Both of these can be found on the cave-story fan website, google is your friend.) He also released this game for free, along with all of the software previously described. I'm not sure what his intention was, but if I had to guess it probably had to do with altruism and entertainment.Phil Fish made Fez in the same timeframe but with crappy unoriginal internet funnies and other despicable internet culture gimmicks.He also charged money from the get-go.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2013
												Cave Story is a fantastic throwback of nostalgia with a mix of combat and platforming that is well worth the $10.The story is simple, but that's fine. You're this little guy that wakes up with no memory of what happened and you find that a race of bunny people (Mimigas) are being abducted from a mad scientist for experiments. You must save them.And how you save them, is the main reason you should buy the game: Sega Genesis/SNES combat in a modern title. There is a variety of different weapons ranging from missile launchers, to pea shooters, to a mario styled fireball thing. The other mechanic in this is platforming, but "true" platforming that is reminiscent of Super Mario and Meat Boy is only present when you're trying to get to power ups, etc. It is more combat focused but that doesn't affect gameplay.Being a nostalgic throwback, Cave Story's graphics pop. If you can get over it being purposefully pixellated, you should enjoy the bright colors of the overworld and gloomy atmosphere of the caves. This does run in 1080p and the pixels are sharp - something that a game like this NEEDS. It runs fine on my rig, but that doesn't mean anything. It probably will run smoothly on a 5 year old Windows XP machine, since it is not a demanding game.If you've grown up with sidescrolling shooters like Metroid and Castlevania, then this is definitely something you should pick up.8.5/10

content:
Posted: July 8, 2013
												This is the archetype of "good indie game."  Its standing is not up for question, nor does it need to be debated.  Its graphics are appealing; its music is catchy as all hell; the gameplay is so well-thought out and it's never frustrating because you're completely in control of your character (Dying is always your fault); the storyline is not hackneyed and it actually motivates the player to, I dunno, play the game.  There simply is no denying that Cave Story is a good game.  I could sing its praises for weeks, but to put it in a nutshell:  if this were released back in the SNES days with the likes of Super Mario World, it would be a long-standing franchise to rival that of Nintendo's greatest accomplishments today.  Everyone should play this game...that's it, that's the end of that statement.  Everyone should play this game.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												The game I've loved since I was in my mid-teens...where do I begin?A platformer originally made in 2004 by one Japanese man named Daisuke Amaya. He has made several other games in this retro style, but this is one of his largest, and obviously most successful, projects.What I love: The retro theme, the silky-smooth gameplay, the music, the corny little story, the items, the endings, the characters, the secrets, and the fact that you can still pick up the original for free. Legally!What I hate: I can't have sex with it. ._.If you like platformers, I would give the free version a look. And if you love that, then consider throwing some money at this version :) There's extra little game modes, and the graphics are given a facelift. Besides, Pixel-san needs more recognition! HYPE THE PIXEL!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This is possibly the best $10 you'll spend.If you were ever a fan of older adventure/platformer games like Metroid, you'll love this game. Everything about this game is absolutely perfect. The chiptune soundtrack is amazing, the graphics actually feel like appropriate (and not the "HD retro" style that you see in a lot of other games that try to emulate the retro visuals), and the controls are tight and responsive.You will NEED a controller to play this game, though. Because - like in many action platformers - you'll be doing a lot of actions all at the same time (jumping, running, dashing, shooting, etc), your fingers are going to be busy, and it only feels right when using a controller.That said, everything about this game is pure nostalgia, without ever feeling like it's pandering to retro gamers at all. While playing Cave Story, it honestly feels like somebody went back in time, stole the source code to a SNES game that was in production, and then brought it back and compiled it all over again for PC.I honestly could think of no problems with this game. It's got great dialogue, the animations are amazing, the gameplay is spectacular, and THE MUSIC. It's a great game that is well worth the pricetag.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
AUDIOGreat OSTVISUALRetroDIFFICULTYDifficulty LevelVIBEMelancholyCRAVINGPlatformerON SALESometimesPROS: Classically-driven Japanese style story that is a touch melancholy, but not nauseatingly-so. Excellent controls and interesting characters. Several soundtrack choices as well as an option for the original graphics. Multiple outcomes for decisions made, as well as weapon options. CONS: Steep difficulty curve near the end is extremely frustrating. Similar to Eversion, you're mainly paying for graphical update and soundtrack options; the entire original game is free. Many will also tell you that this version of the game has unlikeable dialogue changes. Mac players have been having trouble with it as well.WORTH: This developer is a strong but humble contributor to the indie scene. I would highly recommend buying games like this or Kero Blaster at full price to support him.OVERALL: Charming fantasy sci-fi that shows that 2D platformers with pixel art and limited palettes don't have be outcast to the realm of "dated" or "niche." Cave Story was made with a lot of love which has turned it into an outstanding addition to any library. If you feel that supporting this version of the game is wrong for one reason or the other, you may find your money better spent on "Kero Blaster," to support its original creator.SCORE: 10/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Cave Story + is quirky and weird. At first, I thought it was a little too quirky and weird (the first 'boss fight' is against a giant talking handbag), but it quickly grows on you.There's a varied cast of characters that you grow attached to, a degree of freedom in exploration (although your choices narrow off significantly a number of times), and the story is strangely compelling. The retro aesthetic worked well, and I found I enjoyed the game more when I switched back to the old style sprites (you can choose between old and new graphic elements, and old and new music in the menu), likely due to nostalgia. The game just feels like a forgotten gem from the 8 bit / 16 bit era.I started out mildly amused but by the end the story was pulling me through (I stopped studying to come and finish the last 2 hours of the game!), the combat mechanics were fun and engaging and I really enjoyed it. Quirky, charming and nostalgic.

content:
Posted: February 13
												Cave Story+ is a very well-created revision of the charming "Cave Story." Cave Story+ is a very fun game. Although this game can be very difficult at times, and I have yet to complete the best ending, as I'm quite stuck, I think Cave Story+ is a very well-made remaster of the original Cave Story, and it preserves all of the great things about the game, and makes them even better.The combat, though difficult at times, is quite satisfying, and the bosses are fun to fight, and they each have different strategies. The environments in the game are also quite cool, and pretty interesting.The only complaints that I have about the game are that, firstly, it's quite difficult at times, but also, in order for you to get the best ending, there are things you can very easily miss unless informed, so choices and actions can matter quite a lot in this game.Overall, I think Cave Story+ is pretty cool! I would certainly recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed "Cave Story" and everyone who enjoys platforms. The soundtrack was really well-remastered, and has some really catchy tunes!

												Story: You play as an amnesic robot named "Quote" (i guess its from the computer keyboard) who's partner known as "Curly Brace" is lost.. you find yourself in a cave finding an unfinished but powerful gun from a chest that's owned by a tired gunsmith... then you break open a door and you enter Mimiga Village where Sue (spoiler: she's a human) isn't lending the key to King, then the Mimigas, except a few, are missing and turned into monsters destined to kill anything good/nice...Pros: Good Graphics, Great Soundtrack, Retro Gameplay, Perfect Controls, Bindable Controls, and the best level design I've ever seenCons: The SFX do sometimes get really annoyingBCSP:Cave Story Plus is actually a deluxe remake of Doukutsu Monogatari which in English is Cave Story with Better Graphics, Two types of remade soundtracks, more settings, better title screen, and a way better translationLength:2.5 to 4.5 hoursOverall:9.8/10 (You should definitely buy it...)

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												Rating 7.5/10OVerview: 2d Side Scrolling Action/PlatformerThe Good:+ On the surface this game may seem like a standard 2d action game, however once you dig deeper you realize there is more to this little game than you originally thought. As you play you are given choices throughout the game that not only impact the story but even what weapons you can use. All of this leads to some good replaybility and is probably the games' biggest asset+The game has somewhat of a unique upgrade system for the weapons you use. As you kill enemies they drop experience that will increase your weapons level. Each weapon has 3 levels each one getting progressively better. However if you get hit by an enemy your weapon level decreases adding an extra level of complexity to the game.  + A variety of different weapons that fit your play style or situation.  + The game controls are fantastic and feel very responsive+ The game has some really great boss battles, the further you progress in the game the more diverse and unique they become +The game provides a lot of different modes after you beat the game. Each mode requires you to beat it in a certain amount of time, the better you do, the more achievements you get. This further adds to the reaplayability to the game.The Average:Level design and objectives are not that good. Most of the levels have you running to one end of the map only to run back to the beginning again to complete certain objectives and advance the story.  This adds nothing to the gameplay and seems only to be used to pad out the game length. It gets tiring after a while.The Bad:- I really disliked the story and characters. Nothing seems to make sense and about half way through the game I couldn't care what happens to anybody. ConclusionI  had a lot of fun with the game, I just wish the levels were better designed. The extra modes provided are also fun.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Cave Story was the first game I played way back when I first started playing pc games (when I was 5 or 6, so about 11 years ago) when it frist came out as a free downloadable title directly from the site. I loved that game to death. About 2-3 years ago i found out that Cave Story was also on DSiWare and WiiWare, so I quickly bought it on both systems. It was then I realized that the game I played and loved so long ago had a deeper, darker story than what I though it had. Soon after that I lost my DSi, and when I tried to redownload it on my Wii, Nintendo already shut down wifi service for it. I then entered a depressed state, longing to play Cave Story once again...Then one day, while I was browsing Steam on my Grandma's laptop, I saw it. Cave Story+. I had to look twice, for at first I did not believe the wonderous sight before me. I quickly asked my Grandma if I could buy it, and she said yes. From then on out, I was happy. I never felt depressed since. My life was complete.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2012
												This game is one of the best adventure games I have ever played!It's an old game in retro style, which just got updated with High Definition graphic, that's why it's called 'Cave Story+'. (The original Cave Story isn't available on Steam btw)Cave Story is a great 2D game, where you play a robot named 'Quote', who just lost his memories and gets to know what happened the farther you play the game.So, where to start?First off, the Story is quite nice... not the best but it's nice. I don't want to spoil to much but as mentioned, you wake up somewhere and you don't know how you landed there nor what your past is. You have to fight your way through the levels to find out who you are and what you actually did. To reach your goal you'll have to use many different weapons... There's a big arsenal of weapons, but not all of these are obtainable in one single playthrough. The different enemies differ from each other so there's always another strategy how to beat them, the same applies to bosses. The levels are awesome made and the retro graphic style makes this game in it's look beautiful.And if this game was too easy for you, there are a lot of items you can collect and many challenges to complete. In case you aim for all achievements, you'll have to beat this game multiple times because - as mentioned before - you can't get all items in one single playthrough.Anyone who has never played it yet, has something missed in his life. This game is just awesome!You won't regret your buy and you'll love this game!In my opinion maybe the BEST adventure game, which was ever made! :D

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2012/10/cave-story.htmlWhat sets this game apart?Independent developer Pixel spent five years working on this game in his free time, by himself, and produced a game with a compelling story and great retro platforming.  The popularity Cave Story achieved as a freeware title went a long way in proving to the gaming market that you can get a quality product without shelling out $50 to the big production companies.  Surely, this title paved the way for a variety of Xbox Live Arcade, Steam, and even Humble Indy Bundle titles.What is the difficulty factor?Cave Story plays like you would expect most games of its type to play, so there is no tutorial level.  The creator designed the first area in a way to “lets players feel like they've solved problems on their own.”  While it may seem frustrating to learn the hard way that those red spikes will in fact kill you instantly, or that you went the wrong way and have to double back before you can progress, it isn’t like you lose anything for dying, and there are only two ways to go anyway.  Using this sort of tough love tutorial might leave you feeling challenged, but ultimately more accomplished from the very beginning of the game, which sets the tone for the rest of the game.There is certainly no shortage of challenge, here, and even veteran players will experience a few moments where they may feel like pulling their hair out.  Collecting all of the hidden items and choosing the strongest weapons will go a long way in making you successful, but gathering them is a challenging endeavor in itself.  If you are feeling complacent with the difficulty, aim for the secret “good” ending, which features an impossibly difficult series of platforming feats.  In later ports, “hard” mode and a boss run time trial were added for the truly masochistic.Does it use media effectively?While the graphics and music have an enjoyable retro feel to them, and were produced by a single creator, I have to admit that they are not up to par with the technology available.  Later versions, notably Cave Story+ on Steam, cleaned up the graphics and sound while still keeping the retro feel that made it so enjoyable.  The most recent version, a port to the 3DS, was built from the ground up with rendered graphics, stereoscopic 3D, and additional content.  All of the versions are still enjoyable and feature the same level design and gameplay, so just pick the one that fits your visual preference and the limitations of your wallet.Best moment in the game?There are a lot of good moments in this game, but I’m going to have to say that the best moment to me is the boss fight at the end of Sand Zone.  To me, this is the point when the story proves how serious it is going to be.  The dialogue with King and Toroko at this point really hits home, and as the first act comes to a close, you are pumped up and ready to take down the Doctor.Who needs to play this game?This is a modern classic that almost any gamer will enjoy.  Take an NES classic like Metroid, add a compelling story and a bit more linear exploration pattern.  If you have a computer, you have no excuse not to play it, since the original game with a fan translated patch is still available for free (http://www.cavestory.org/downloads_game.php)!  If you are willing to spend a few bucks, I would personally suggest getting your hands on the DSi or Steam release, as they have some additional features that extend the replayability of the game.

content:
Posted: February 1
												Well, after 100 hours on this game, I think I can write a review about it. So is it a game that you will enjoy and get addicted to or a game that you will dislike? The only one who could reply is you, but here is my personal opinion about it. You should enjoy it, unless you don't like platformer games. There are plenty of things that I liked, which I am going to analyse now.   First of all, the story is quite interesting and most importantly, the ending can be changed depending on your actions in the game. You can choose the bad ending, which is the quick solution, the normal ending that you will get 99.99% on your first try and the best ending, the most difficult one. Nevertheless, the story is as follows: You are a robot, who was sent among hundreds of others, a lot of years ago for one purpose: to defeat the Doctor, the villain in the story. In this "universe", there are bunnies in the shape of humans called Mimigas who are being kidnapped by him in order to eat the red flowers. If they consume them, they become enraged and uncontrollable. Yes, I know, it's a little weird, but you get used to it as the time goes by. Anyway, you start from a cave, get your first weapon and continue with the story as a guide. I liked the fact that it was balanced, the jokes, the weird moments, everything.   Secondly, I bet that you will be surprised if you hear that it was made by a man. Exactly, only one man, named Daisuke Amaya. He has made a lot of other games in the same style that I haven't personally tried, but I am willing to. He is the one who made the sprites, the music and the story. Speaking of music, the soundtrack is really catchy. It's so good that you will actually repeat it to yourself alone at least 15 times ( If you like 8 bit music ) . The art is neither bad nor good, it's exactly as I expected it to be.   On the other hand, the only real disadvantage that I found regarding this game is its cost. I might be a little too strict about these kinds of things, but 15 euros for this seems too much, don't you think? I could get a cool CS:GO skin with this or something even better. In my opinion, it would be better if it had costed 10 euros or so.   All in all, from my point of view, Cave Story+ deserves a 8,5/10. It's a great game that everyone who loves pixel games should try out. I wanted to give it a higher mark, but its cost made me to think about it twice.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												[Note: I have not played the original freeware Cave Story or any of its other versions, so this review will be for the Cave Story+ Steam version only.]I absolutely love Cave Story.  It is truly a great callback to SNES-era games such as Super Metroid, managing to incorporate all the best aspects of the period's game design while also finding room for some cool modern features (difficulty settings, skins, graphics/music options, achievements, and extended modes).  I'll break up this review  into sections, with each one focusing on a core aspect of the game:[Gameplay]This cannot be praised enough.  Like that of Super Metroid, Cave Story's gameplay combines the 2-D platformer, shooter, and RPG genres to create a wonderful but difficult experience.  There are nine weapons (mostly guns) in the game, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.  A levelling system is applied to each gun you possess- your guns get EXP when you defeat enemies and acquire energy triangles, but lose EXP when you take damage.  As expected, guns become more powerful when you level up (with one exception).  This is an interesting and dynamic system, but can be very punishing for a careless player.  The game has a lot of secrets, and considerable backtracking is required to find everything.  Levels and bosses start off easy, but quickly become very difficult, especially when you're trying to get the true ending.  To give you an idea, I spent around 20 hours on Normal difficulty beating the last level + final boss alone.  The lack of save points before boss battles can be very annoying... just so you know what you're getting into.[Graphics]The graphics would look right at home on the SNES, featuring nice sprites and beautiful pixel-art environments.  The "remastered" graphics basically quadruple the number of pixels per sprite, and I greatly prefer them.  The original graphics are a bit barebones for my taste, although of course there's nothing really wrong with them.[Music]Music is another area in which this game shines.  The remastered music features a combination of chiptune and lower-quality (MIDI?) instruments, while the original is all chiptune.  Once again, I preferred the remastered versions here, as the original sometimes hurt my ears.  The tunes themselves are very catchy, and always fit the environment/context in which they are played.  Despite being somewhat minimalistic, the music manages to evoke many different feelings: comfort, exhiliration, dread, misery, you name it.  Definitely going in my playlist.[Story/Characters]The story is fairly simple but very solid.  I'm not going to give anything away as I think it's best experienced completely blind; and apparently, the game thinks so as well, as it just drops you in the middle of the first level with no explanation!  You have to figure out the story and the setting as you go along, and it's a ride.  Your story-related choices in this game aren't as varied as in other indie RPGs (e.g. Undertale), but there are a lot of sad moments.  When I played this game for the first time, I always felt like I was doomed until the very end.  My only real complaint is that the final boss isn't mentioned until LATE in the game- I felt like he could've been introduced a little better than he was.[Replayability]Basically endless!  There are three endings, three difficulty modes, and a lot of optional challenges (a new level, Boss Attack, time trials, etc.).  This is an incredibly tough game to 100% as it has speedrun achievements.  We'll see how close I get...Overall: 93/100

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												This is going to be in the list of memorable games.If you're searching for something new, or at least with some variaty, you have to play this. It's unique story makes it really intesting to continue (Even though I'm not a story guy, I still admired it). It's technically one of those games that says: "Screw reality! Let's go for imagination!", which 95% of all games doesn't do nowadays. Throughout you play the game, you'll confront different entities that you haven't seen before. The first ones are the Mimigas. They also play an important role in the game, so don't forget about them. Later on, you'll confront other types of entities. But remember this: You have never seen them before in your life.It also have the feel of the old games. It's not really difficult like the old games but it has some of the thinking from the time. For example, there is bosses (Loads of them), no health recharge (All new games has that, and I think games are too easy with it), manual saving (Using save points) and so forth.But there's one negative side with this game, though. And it's that the story is very involving. And if you know games: The more story it is, the less gameplay. That leaves the player with dialogs and cutscenes where the player doesn't do much other than watching things happen. And what I think about games are that gameplay is the most important thing. Because when I play a game I want to stay in control throughout the whole game. That's what I like with games like Snayke or Doom.Still, an amazing game. Even though of the negative side, the positive sides overwhelmes that side of the game. I also made a playthrough on this game on YouTube.Here's the link to my montage of my playthrough (If you're still unsure about buying it):

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Cave Story+ is a famous Japanese independent game that was originally released as freeware with a fan translation. This re-release offers a choice of playing with the original graphics and music, or the remastered graphics and music. Whatever your choice may be, the game is a well done fanfare reminiscent of the classic platform games on the NES and SNES. The keyboard controls takes some getting used to even though they are simple to learn, but you do have the option of rebinding the keys and using a gamepad. The plot is comparable the well established lore of yesteryear by being invited to save people and rid a world of evil. The enemies are stereotypically Japanese in design, as well as the overall game mechanics and boss battles. Some of the dialog can be slightly amusing and sometimes charming, but this once again, does not steer too much away from what we have grown accustomed to enjoy from the 80s and 90s console eras. The difficulty settings can be adjusted to your liking, and they each provide an adequate challenge depending on what option you have decided to go for. The power-up system rewards the players who go out of their way to collect dropped items from downed foes. Switching between each weapon rapidly can be tricky, but this does not hinder the player from enjoying the changes, as adapting comes somewhat quickly through your progress. The different weapons acquired throughout the game are all quite useful and play very different from each other. As you change between them, there is much satisfaction shooting down your enemies and conquering bosses. While the storyline is reminiscent of past decades, it is surprisingly unique, in addition to flowing and developing well. This appealing plot provides the player with plenty of entertainment for many hours as you progress through the story. After tougher areas or tougher boss battles, your weapons' levels go down quite a bit as you take damage, and gathering the necessary drops in order to get them back to full power can be a chore. Cave Story+ is full of retro charm, from its game play style to its artistic inventions. There is very little to complain about, as I cannot think of any serious flaws. The resolution settings do not allow for true full screen, as black borders will be placed at the sides. The platforming elements in conjunction with the shooting can sometimes take some skill and getting used to, especially in high action sections. Some portions of the game (namely some bosses) become quite frustrating, no matter what difficulty setting you are playing on. This forces the player to redo a part of the game again in order to face the same boss (or bosses). Each repetition is about five minutes or longer, which constitutes of a problem to me, as dying with certain bosses occurs often. It is a game that may not be for everyone if the genre is not to their liking, but overall, it is quite the accomplishment, especially if you keep in mind that it was designed entirely by one single person, and achieves such positive results. The music is nothing short of superb. It embodies all that was great from the 8-bit and 16-bit eras and makes it exceptional and complementing to the game's presentation and plot. There is also a considerable amount of replay ability, as there are unlockable game modes and four different endings. If you love platform games with shooter elements, this is a must play. If you are unsure about the genre, you owe it to yourself to give this indie classic a try.Cave Story+ is great.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2011
												An undeniable 'Modern Classic', and an astounding one-man project that is finally appearing in a digital storefront after 5 years as freeware.This story-driven, side-scrolling platformer-shooter opens with no details on where you are, what the goal is or who your character is (although I can tell you that he's called Quote; it's never mentioned anywhere in the game). The plot is linear in a MetroidVania way, but the decisions you make will alter the dialogue, the weapons you can get, and unlock alternative endings; for example, if you come across the item with "0.8" in the name, it's recommended that you skip it instead of taking it.The "+" signifies the conversion job done by a studio called Nicalis, who re-translated the text and added new sound, graphics and game modes to ports for the Wii and DSiWare, finally adding these options to the PC version. I play with New Graphics and Old Sound enabled, but would definitely go "HUZZAH!" if the original English script was available.

This is a great platformer with engaging storyline, unique set of characters, funny and well-written dialogue, an arsenal of inventive weapons, secret chambers, chests and upgrades, humongous range of bosses to fight agains. The game features three different endings and two graphical settings to choose from: original or remastered; as well as three types of soundtrack: original, remastered and brand new one written especially for Wii release of the game. number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												One of the greatest and most influential games of all time, with one of the most unnecessary remakes of all time. At best the additions are novel. Most of the songs in the "remastered" soundtrack are fine, but not better than the original. There are added difficulty modes that just change the amount of health you have, and while the easy mode is good for inexperienced players the game's difficulty curve was already very well crafted in the first place. Hard mode just forces you to not pick up any health upgrades, something simple to do if you wanted to impose it on yourself in the original. The other extra game modes are not substantial.At worst the "additions" actually detract from the experience. One of the 3 optional soundtrack options is an abomination. The extra fidelity on the sprites is often a step backward: you can see a more of some characters' facial features but their expressions never change so it looks soulless. Their official translation often feels like it was trying too hard not to be the original fan translation, adding some cheap jokes and removing classic lines. The only circumstance where I would reccomend you get this version of the game is if you want to support the developer who spent 5 years making the original and released it for free. Even then, I don't know how much money actually goes to him and not the company who took a free game and made a bunch of unwanted changes just so they could charge people for it.If you do end up playing this version of the game first, play it with the included options for original soundtrack and art. You can try the updated visuals and music on your inevitable repeat playthrough, because you will love this game.It's sad when the best way to play a premium version of the game is to emulate the free version as closely as possible.

content:
Posted: April 4
												While cave story is one of the greatest indie games ever made, Cave Story+ is a terrible port. Cave Story+ is terrible because it it runs in 4:3, the problem with that is even the freeware version runs in 16:9. You can't even stretch the game to 16:9, black borders were physcially added to the game to make it dispay in "16:9".  I would suggest to play the free game first instead, here are some comparisons. Free: http://i.imgur.com/1pA2Zc1.png Paid: http://imgur.com/LsDIJ1q The improvements in  the paid are double resolution textures, challenges and Curly story. These improvements are not worth it though. If you want the improvements but you don't want 4:3 then you should really buy the wiiware version. You can play the wiiware version on pc with Dolphin. To do this you need a hombrewed wii. You need to buy the wiiware version. You then need to dump the NAND through Bootmii. You then need to decrypt it and copy it into Dolphin. This it worth is though: http://imgur.com/IqaVZrV As a bonus you get full controller support, upscaling and antianalising.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												It's Cave Story- play it.EDIT:  Some people have not heard about this still, I suppose, so... it is a one man project from 2005 that inspired the makers of Super Meat Boy and is credited with a rise in indie developers trying to accomplish larger tasks outside of their niche group.  After it's freeware release it was remade to all late 21st century Nintendo consoles, and fans made it portable to the original Xbox and some graphing calculators (along with Mac and Linux).After all these years critics have called it the "King of the Indies", commending it for its masterful game design and storytelling.Even if you do not like semi-open/branching world story-driven 2D sidecrolling shoot'em-ups, then this game is worth a purchase, because being a PC gamer in this golden age of indie development and not looking into Cave Story means missing out on how our culture has developed, and what values started it all.  It is the same thing as being a huge fan of Naruto and One Piece but never taking a look at Dragon-Ball (even if the show REALLY repels you), or reading great modern fantasy like Game of Thrones or Tad Williams without reading The Hobbit and Lord of the Rings.Chances are you will love it anyway.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Overall a good game and nothing was enough to make me hate it, but there are still several design choices that keep in from being a 100% must-have in my book. Most of it is fine, but once we get to the end of the Sand Zone and get to Rabid Toroko we start to hit some problems.For one, Toroko is a pretty disorienting curveball in herself; depending on what she decides to do the fight can either be quick and painless or teeth-grindingly annoying. And to top it off, after beating her you don't have the opportunity to heal for a lengthy period of time afterward (likely trying to see if they can force you to use the Life Pot item that fully recovers your health just once in mid-game; which by the way is a HUGE mistake).However, that isn't close to being the worst part. That comes immediately after: the Labyrinth. I hate the whole level in its entirety (and no, not for Monster X. He was actually the good thing to come out of it in my opinion). Its actual design is a bit jarring at points with several stunts that require almost perfect timing to pull off, but the biggest reason I hate it is that it can screw you over from 100% completion in several ways, all of which can occur VERY easily. The first example is when someone falls into one of the rooms as you enter; you can either talk to him and pick up something now or ignore him and move on for something else later. To even have a chance at 100%, you have to be a jerk and ignore the guy, going into the next room (which, by the way, has a boss fight almost immediately). And what makes this an even bigger problem is that the jump required to make it past him is very easy to miss, with no chance whatsoever to climb back up without talking to the guy who fell or resetting and trying the jump again (and even when you do eventually make it, the remainder of the Labyrinth will be an even bigger burden on you.The boss following that jerkishly designed jump isn't too bad; in fact it's a cakewalk with the right weapon choices, but what follows soon after is my least favorite segment of the entire game at the very end of the level, which is flooded with water that continually rises and falls as you go, and this is where that one bit I mentioned earlier starts to come further into play. If you went down to meet the guy who fell, the item you need to have any chance at completion will somehow magically vanish from this room (how does that make any sense?). If you didn't, you won't have better air movement to arm you against the Island Core, where the designer apparently didn't realize that having to deal with constant water physics that make no sense paired with the endless attacks and getting pulled and pushed around at will doesn't point toward a very good boss fight.Following that (by the way, also with no healing opportunities after an annoying fight) is the final stretch of the area, the Waterway, which introduces water currents that pulls you along. The area itself isn't too bad minus the huge abundance of spikes, but another very likely chance to miss 100% AND a reasonable save point is right around the corner, requiring about a split second's notice to jump off a single block out into a shack before the currents catch you again, and following that is the labyrinth's fifth and last boss (which I hate for the opposite reason of the Core; being too easy and coming right the heck out of nowhere anyways).Thankfully, the game stops being jerkish after that point until the very end if you happen to discover the hidden level you were working toward to get the best ending, and long story short to first-timers... This area WILL be the bane of your sanity. You have been warned.

												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a MetroidVania Platform game.Interface/Menu/SettingsThere are different modes.You can play this game in fullscreen or windowed mode.You can't change the resolution size.There is a Music Volume button bar. The more to the right, the higher the volume.There is a Sound Volume button bar. The more to the right, the higher the volume.You can play this game with a controller or keyboard. You are able to change the controls of the controller or keyboard.There is a difficulty settings.Main Menu is pretty good and you can change the music style into "retro/remastered or new"About the game.You are playing with a girl that is lost in a cave. During your adventure you will encounter enemies and weird rabbits. You will also find a gun and by killing enemies. They will have a chance to drop a Experience shard. Once the meter bar is full, your level of the gun will increase and you will do more damage. Taking damage by enemies/obstacles will decrease the experience meter. There are save stations and health stations all over the place. You can only save at the stations and not manually.The music that you have chosen at the main menu will also affect ingame.There is no options/settings ingame.The game has a decent story.Music is okay.Graphics are oldschool.Game has some funny things.Save stations are the only place to save your game.You can't skip dialogues or chat conversations.Other things.-------------------I Give this game a 6/10

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Cave Story+ is a 16-bit "Metroidvania" platformer created by Nicalis. You play as Quote, a robot soldier discharged from an old war in which you use your array of weapons to stop the Doctor. Cave Story features an amazing story which also contains alternate endings based on your actions throughout the game. This game has been released on multiple platforms such as the Nintendo Wii, 3DS and of course, Steam. This version features an enhanced versioin of Cave Story, with cleaner graphics and remastered soundtrack, as well as challenges and achievements. The achievements are simple to get, most of them can be achieved during your first run of the game. Others require to complete certain objectives and replaying the game. The challenges can be challenging, but it does give the player some elements aside from the main game.Highly recommended for people who love an amazing story and a general fanatic of platformers. High replayability, alternate endings and challenges. Best version of Cave Story. Rating: 9.0/10

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
Cave Story+I absoloutely love this game, but I absoloutely hate how impossible it is to get the ending you want the first time without using guides.Do I recommend it? Yes!I also recommend playing it on easy difficulty the first time! Otherwise, you could spend hours being stuck due to some boss battle. Tons of achievements that are fun to get, plenty of secrets/"easter eggs"Gorgeous soundtrack and graphics, and the story is amazing. Now go buy it. Why are you still reading? Go buy it!If you're still reading, you hopefully already own the game, and you've beaten it.Major spoilers are coming up, so stop reading now if you don't want spoilers.Here's a story of a kid who decided to buy Cave Story for Wii. He started playing the game, and honestly, he loved it. He played it for hours every day, and eventually he met a girl named Curly. Curly was a robot, just like the player this kid was controlling. He grew very emotionally attached to Curly quite quickly, and he got to a point where he had to fight a boss. Due to Cave Story's weird ending system that this kid had no idea about, he couldn't save Curly, and she drowned. This made the kid cry for hours. This kept him awake at night years later. (No joke, and I'm not exaggerating here.) And he beat the game. For a long time, he didn't return to Cave Story. He was too sad. Years later, he got on Steam one day, and saw something in the store called Cave Story+. He decided to buy it, because he really liked Cave Story. He played it, and he beat the game and got the best ending. He saved Curly. He was so happy, and he slept better at night. If you haven't guessed yet, this kid was me. Thanks for putting this on Steam.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Cave Story is an indie adventure game in the tradition of Metroid, Kid Icarus and Simon's Quest. It combines classic pixel platforming with exploration, a large open world and an assortment of collectible weapons and upgrades. While it visually looks like a much more polished verison of a game from that age, Cave Story also includes some enhanced features like a storyline reminiscent of Japanese RPGs and an in-game map like later "metroidvania" games. Cave Story does not do much by way of innovating; it is very much, at its core, an adventure platformer. However it is a very good action platformer that appeals to my sense of nostalgia and fills the need quick action platformer type games. It is definitely worth some time if you are looking for a metroidvania game or get the itch to play Super Metroid or Symphony Of The Night but want a game you have not already played.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												EDIT: They rose the price instead of having a sale this Christmas. The developers are as bad as you may have heard.So I'm going to start off by saying that I have the free-ware version of the game that was released in 2004. And the 3D version released in 2012. And the 3DS-Ware version that was released in 2013. What I'm trying to say is, I spent another $20 on this game (a copy for myself and my brother) because I knew exactly what I was buying, and I wanted to support this game even further. Cave Story is a side-scrolling shooter where you play as robot soldier, who wakes up in a small cave with no idea who he is or what's happening on the island around him. Cave Story+ has several more features then the original Cave Story, including several time trial challenges, an unlockable mode where you play the game as another chracter, enhanced graphics, a remastered sound track, a "new" soundtrack, and over 70 achievements to reward you on doing anything from killing a boss wihout taking damage to... not killing a fish. Seriously. There's an achevement for not killing a fish. So, Mr. Traveler, grab your Polar Star and save the island!

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												A very enjoyable little retro game with a quite interesting story. You start as this person who has no memory of what happened and you soon find out you are on a floating island and a evil mad Doctor is plotting to take over the world and become ruler of all. You meet many interesting characters along the way as well as some memorable villains and there are different endings depending on how you play the game and what routes you take.A surprising amount of fun and controller use recommended for this title. Hell of a lot of fun and well worth the price :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Cave Story is my favorite game to ever come out of the indie scene. It has a lot of charm, a great soundtrack, and fantastic gameplay. It's kinda like a MetroidVania but really doesn't feel like Metroid or Castlevania. I think that's what it does right the best out of all the indie games I've played, it takes a lot of old ideas but makes something really fresh and new out of them. It doesn't depend on nostalgia to be a good game; it just uses good gameplay mechanics and makes them unique. If you like games like Metroid or MegaMan and want something fresh to remind you why you liked those games in the first place, check this game out.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												I played the freeware version way back when and this is basically that +1. The new sprites look really smooth and the addition of several save files and some different modes increase the already initially large amount of replayability. I stil prefer the classic music, however.As for the game itself, it's a Metroid/Castlevania style of game where you collect power ups and weapons in an open style of world. It also has quite an interesting plot if you get into it.Tl;dr if you don't want to buy what I consider to be the greatest indie game ever, at least google up the old freeware version and play that. This is not a game to miss out on.

I didn't have this on Steam yet, so ... 												Recommended with some remarks.Old School plataform game. Cute characters, simplist scenarios but, attracting, at the end.Hard. Another thing that I hate is that every time you enter in any room, the complete scenario resets and the already killed enemies respawn.It would be a perfect game if it allowed to save the progress at any time.To repeat several times same thing is boring and kills the overall charming of the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Cave Story is an indie adventure game in the tradition of Metroid, Kid Icarus and Simon's Quest. It combines classic pixel platforming with exploration, a large open world and an assortment of collectible weapons and upgrades. While it visually looks like a much more polished verison of a game from that age, Cave Story also includes some enhanced features like a storyline reminiscent of Japanese RPGs and an in-game map like later "metroidvania" games. Cave Story does not do much by way of innovating; it is very much, at its core, an adventure platformer. However it is a very good action platformer that appeals to my sense of nostalgia and fills the need quick action platformer type games. It is definitely worth some time if you are looking for a metroidvania game or get the itch to play Super Metroid or Symphony Of The Night but want a game you have not already played.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2013
												I cry, everytime. The game stands the test of age - the work of only one programmer, suddenly having to be "Remastered" by a team of dozens of people is nothing short of a prodigy.The game has tons of replay value, and secrets that have you second guessing and save-stating the loving hell of out the game to make sure you don't mess up.The game is challenging, but not impossible. I only had to cheat in it because I, like most young people, got tired of dying more often then my member as I go through my Dark Souls ecchi collection.The point is, the Japanese don't only make good anime, food, and women; they make good video games as well. 10/10, would try before I buy again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												I can't possibly recommend this game more to more people. It's not very long and the graphics aren't amazing, but the gameplay is positively top-notch and the story is very intriguing. Both will drive you through to the end and leave you wanting more, and when that time comes you'll find that there's a lot more to the experience when you dig deeper and make different choices.The added offerings from the freeware version make this game more than worth the price, even to veterans of the original. Hard mode will test your skill and patience and the added modes will give players a lot more to do even after they've beaten every story path and difficulty level. The graphics and music switches are also much appreciated. There are 3 versions of the soundtrack and old and new graphics to play with, so you're sure to find a mode you like.Really, if you haven't played this indie masterpiece, you owe it to yourself as a gamer to drop whatever you're playing and hop into Cave Story.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Who knew that an 8-bit game could make you cry, well this game did and then some; with its deep storyline and intreging characters each with their own personalities, you can't help but feel attached to them.The game has an excellent soundtrack that you'll find yourself listening to long after turning off the game.Cave Story+ is a sort of remake of Cave Story that was released in Japan in 2004 with improved visuals and sound, also adds some extra modes like the "Challenge mode" where you can test you platforming skill in increasingly difficult puzzles. The game combines the best of old NES games like Megaman, Final Fantasy, and Super Metroid into one excellent package.I can't recommend this game enough, I give this game a 10/10

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Cave story, not a story about portals (get it? cave, cave jonson? eh me neither >_<)Where do i start besides the very fitting title? I must say this was a very surprising find for me. I mean, this game has so many reincarnations that theres no surprise that its one of the best games ive played. I honestly think this is how the indie platform began, and they did a damn good job doing it.-Exellent controlls and well responsive platforming make for a tight and enjoyable experience-Fantastic and exquisite soundtrack that makes you want to get the soundtrack and spam the hell out of grasslands-Memorable characters despite not much screentime, like king for example. Where did he get that scar from anyways?-The story is the most epic and cliffhanging experiences ive ever had. The swift and wonderful experience makes for the perfect game for a indie nerd such as myselfFinal rating for the game? well 5/5. i know its kinda generic to go with the croud but i cant bash a game so great.

content:
Posted: March 8
												This is tied for my favorite game of all time. I've bought it on all sorts of systems, but never finished it on Steam, so mind the relative lack of hours and achievements. Cave Story was originally released free in 2004, and was made by just one man over the course of five years. Since the initial release, the game has undergone many remakes and ports. The Steam version of Cave Story is the definitive version, in my opinion. (Although the 3DS version *does* have a jukebox feature.) You can get the original version of this game from a quick Google search, and it was actually released for free. If you're not sure if this game is for you, I suggest trying out the original version of the game, playing it for an hour or two and if you like it, buy this version to play instead.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												Don't be fooled by my low play time. I've been a Cave Story enthusiast since before CS+ existed. I bought this game because I want money to go to Pixel, because he's a boss.What is Cave Story?Well, once upon a time a really smart guy looked at emerging computer technology and said, "What if we use this to have fun?" For a while things were great, but then the dreaded 'Video Games Industry' came and took all the fun away, replacing it with things like 'features' and 'innovation' and blah blah blah. Everyone was sad.Then Pixel rode in on a white horse, weilding a 20 string electric guitar and a legendary sword that shoots awesomeness and bacon. Our mighty hero dropped trou and took a fat dump on the stale industry's stupid hi-res face. Then he made the GREATEST GAME OF ALL TIME and gave it away for free. (You can get the original CS with bonus materials for free on the CS website.)And the moral of the story is: NOW YOU CAN BE A HAPPY PERSON.Cave Story recaptures the soul of classic NES and SNES era games. It does everything right that those games did, and then it does everything right that those games didn't. Every inch of the game radiates pure fun and excellent design, and you don't have to play long before you realize that this is something that someone made for the love of the game rather than to try and squeeze another nickel out of you with the latest lame gimmick. Cave Story seems like a simple metroidvania platformer, but don't be fooled. There are cool secrets hidden all over the place. The game just plays so smoothly that you don't even realize that you're making plot decisions and weapons selections as you go along. If you like to have fun then go grab the Ultimate CS pack from the website and play the game. When you've finished crying ecstatic tears of reverent joy, you'll want to buy CS+. Not for the new bonus modes, not for the remastered graphics and music, not even for the steam acheivements. You'll want to buy CS+ out of sheer gratitude.Now go forth! Be happy!

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												I love Cave Story. In fact, I bought this simply to show support for Pixel, who is amazing; the amount of time and effort that went into the original is actually rather inspiring for a one man project. That said, what I paid money for was the original content, not what came with +.I hate the new graphics and music, they're ugly to both senses. The translation, the most subjective part, to me is inferior to the original fan translation way back when. The only positive I can claim is that Curly Mode is a cute little different take on the whole game, but it's not something that can carry such a large price tag.If you love the original Cave Story and want to toss some money at Pixel, then hey, buy it like me. If you've never played Cave Story, do so with the original freeware version, because there is nothing really here for any first time players.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2013
												I really enjoyed playing this game. From the beautiful pixel art and the 16-bit music, to the Metroidvania style, and the lovely characters. There are lots of moments that make you love the characters. Bad things appeared very soon into the game, as I got a map, but didn't know how to use it. Controls aren't well explained; I had to look for them in a website.There's a high amount of achievements that make the game longer, experience points, levels, powers, lots of items, cool boss fights and other things that are common in Metroidvanias.So, my conclusion is: this game is awesome. It was in the last Humble Bundle, so there are lots of people who have it but haven't tried it yet (like me some hours ago). Give it a try; you've got nothing to lose.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
												Considering that the original game if free, if you're not going to play it for the challenge modes there is no real reason for spending $15 on this version.My time with Cave Story has not been the greatest. I found most ‘puzzles’ to be tedious and largely consisting of backtracking through levels that felt relatively lifeless.Saving constantly was required as sometimes, out of nowhere, you’d drop into a small bit of spikes that would instantly kill you, whereas the enemies in that region could barely scratch you. Either that or there wouldn’t be a save point for 15 minutes.Cave Story’s infamous weapon level system acted to me as, "You’re doing poorly? Now you’re doing worse!”, rather than something that rewards mashing the fire button occasionally.The story was slow and rather random and something I ended up not really caring about.While advancing, apparently I explored too much before moving on and now don't have the booster shoes and killed everyone, forcing me to have to google where I was supposed to go next. I also switched out for the machine gun early on, having no idea that I'd be missing out on the best weapon in the game later.Basically, I had seen this game around for years and expected it to be a masterpiece but ended up never really having any moments of enjoyment while playing through Cave Story.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												This game is just awesome.Cave Story+ is a great game, it has decent gameplay, and the graphics aren't too shabby either.  (Although it is not very common to find a game in a more pixelated style these days.)  One thing I like about the control scheme is that you can, well, modify which button corresponds to which control in the game.  As expected, the controls in-game are responsive, like movement and shooting.  Additionally, the game gives off a very retro style due to its pixel style.  (You can even set the graphics to "Original" for an even more retro experience, although I'd recommend "New" because they look more refined.)There is one downside to this game, though.  This game only has a Story Mode and Curly Story mode with three saves each, and a few special challenge levels.  There isn't much else to do in the game, however the difficulty modes and options to trade weapons within the game (aquiring special weapons from NPCs, there is no actual trading in the Cave Story games) do add some replay value.  There are three endings in total, and if you're trying to get a specific ending (I won't tell which one) you'll have to go through a secret stage after the "canon" events of the game.  The secret level has a surprise at the end..  You'll have to find out yourself if you want to know what it is.I initially was not knowledgeable that you could shoot upwards and downwards, and so I only shot left and right.  When I actually figured out about the full firing capabilities, I face-palmed and said to myself, "This isn't Megaman, I can shoot up and down!" (So you can shoot upwards and downwards, now you know.)If you buy this game on Steam or the other ports on 3DS and Wii, or even if you download the original version from the Internet, hopefully this review will be useful to you.9.5/10, very good game!

												In my opinion, Cave Story is the pinnacle of metroidvania platformers.Fantastic, retro inspired, graphical style.Tight, frame precise, controls.Excellent soundtrack that doesn't pund your eardrums.Plenty of replayability, multiple endings and several player choices affecting gameplay.Endearing story and cute characters.One of the few "true" indie games. It's made by one guy, Pixel.The original is freeware, the Cave Story+ version available on steam has multiple soundtrack and graphics options for either a retro or more modern HD feel (mix and match if you want), new game modes (speed trials and rush, etc), and controller compatibility. ~Nominated for the Steam Awards 2016 - The "Test of Time" Award~

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Cave Story is kinda supposed to be a modern classic metroidvania action platformer, but I can't really say that I found it any more than average in it's gameplay mechanics and design.  The action itself is ok, but somewhat repetitive however there are a couple mechanics that are REALLY annoying.  The weapon leveling sounds good at first but the ease with which you lose the weapon levels causes lots of trouble mid-battle, and more importantly wastes a ton of time with grinding, checkpointing and then getting going again;  which slows down the pacing considerably if you want your weapons fully leveled ... and you do, because the fights can be quite challenging.  A good deal of the challenge though comes just from the widely spaced checkpoints which are quite annoying, especially if you have to go back through the same grindy level bits and unskippable cut scenes to get back to a failed boss battle which is a shame because they would be very good battles if you weren't already in a bad mood from having to grind and cut scene your way back to them ... So that's the bad side on the better side the sound track is EXCELLENT chip tune inspired work, probably the best element of the game, and there are a lot of tracks which are well placed and distributed.  I suppose the story itself is pretty interesting and unique but leaves quite a bit unanswered, which is fine.  Conclusion: I'm not sorry that I played Cave Story+, but the amount of time that it wastes in between the good bits is sufficient to keep me from recommending it.
